Title: Abstract
Definition: An entity encompassing pure concepts, independent of physical, mental, or social instantiation.

Title: Foundations of Abstraction
Definition: A fundamental class of core, non-physical principles and entities.

Title: Axiomatic System
Definition: A foundational logical construct built upon unproven assertions to derive valid theorems.

Title: Axiomatic Logical System
Definition: A structured framework for deriving truths from foundational assumptions and inference rules.

Title: Axiomatic Probability System
Definition: A formal mathematical structure for quantifying uncertainty and randomness.

Title: Axiomatic Order-Theoretic System
Definition: An abstract framework for rigorously defining relationships between elements using fundamental principles.

Title: Axiomatic Graph-Theoretic System
Definition: A formal mathematical framework establishing graph properties through fundamental postulates.

Title: Axiomatic Analytical System
Definition: A foundational mathematical structure defining real numbers and their metric properties axiomatically.

Title: Axiomatic Functional-Analysis System
Definition: A rigorous framework defining infinite-dimensional spaces and their operators.

Title: Axiomatic Quantum-Logic System
Definition: A formal framework describing quantum mechanics via algebraic structures, notably orthomodular lattices.

Title: Axiomatic Algebraic System
Definition: A formal mathematical structure defined by foundational postulates.

Title: Axiomatic Set-Theoretic System
Definition: A formal system establishing foundational rules for collections and their constituents.

Title: Axiomatic Arithmetic System
Definition: A formal mathematical framework establishing number properties through postulates.

Title: Axiomatic Geometric System
Definition: A formal mathematical framework grounded in fundamental propositions describing spatial relationships and figures.

Title: Axiomatic Type/Category System
Definition: A system for rigorously classifying abstract entities using fundamental principles.

Title: Axiomatic Non-Classical System
Definition: A formal framework of postulates and inference rules for logical systems beyond classical scope.

Title: Axiomatic Topological System
Definition: A fundamental structure characterized by subsets adhering to specific open set axioms.

Title: Axiomatic Measure-Theoretic System
Definition: A precisely defined abstract structure for assigning magnitudes to sets.

Title: Universal Property
Definition: An abstract characteristic defining an object via unique relationships with others.

Title: Object-Level Universal Property
Definition: A characteristic defining an object through its unique relational structure with all other relevant entities within a specific context.

Title: Cone-Level Universal Property
Definition: A defining property that uniquely characterizes an object via its relationship to other objects in a category.

Title: Cocone-Level Universal Property
Definition: A unique mapping property defining a colimit object as an initial cocone.

Title: Diagram-Level Universal Property
Definition: An abstract categorical characteristic defined by a unique arrow that factors through a specified diagram.

Title: Functor-Level Universal Property
Definition: An abstract property uniquely characterizes a functor via a universal natural transformation.

Title: End/Coend-Level Universal Property
Definition: A characterization defining generalized limits and colimits via natural transformations.

Title: Infinitary Concept
Definition: An abstraction involving concepts of endlessness in quantity, extent, or duration.

Title: Infinitary Logic
Definition: A formal system permitting formulas of infinite length or infinite quantifiers.

Title: Topological Compactification
Definition: A process of adjoining boundary points to a topological space to make it compact.

Title: Projective Limit
Definition: A system limit is a fundamental construction in category theory.

Title: Inductive Limit
Definition: A mathematical construction representing a colimit of a direct system.

Title: Infinite Combinatorics
Definition: An exploration of discrete structures with immeasurable quantity.

Title: Cardinal Arithmetic
Definition: A mathematical system for comparing and combining sizes of sets, including infinite ones.

Title: Ordinal Arithmetic
Definition: A system of operations extending basic arithmetic to transfinite numbers based on order types.

Title: Transfinite Recursion
Definition: An ordinal-based method for defining sequences or functions beyond finite steps.

Title: Infinite Series
Definition: A summation of an unlimited number of terms following a specific pattern.

Title: Infinite Products
Definition: An expression that systematically multiplies an endless series of mathematical values.

Title: Infinite-Dimensional Structures
Definition: A mathematical space requiring an infinite number of basis vectors for a complete description.

Title: Power Set Construction
Definition: A set containing all possible subsets of a given collection.

Title: Metric Completion
Definition: A topological space formed by adding limits of Cauchy sequences.

Title: Metamathematical Theory
Definition: A rigorous examination of formal mathematical systems using mathematical techniques.

Title: Proof Theory
Definition: A formal investigation into the structure and validity of mathematical arguments.

Title: Forcing Theory
Definition: An approach to demonstrating independence through generic extensions of models.

Title: Ordinal Analysis
Definition: A method for evaluating proof strength using ordinal numbers.

Title: Descriptive Set Theory
Definition: An area of mathematics concerning the properties of definable sets.

Title: Stability/Classification Theory
Definition: A field studying the properties and types of mathematical structures.

Title: Finite Model Theory
Definition: A branch of logic focused on the properties of models with finite universes.

Title: Realizability Theory
Definition: A constructive interpretation of mathematical proofs.

Title: Game Semantics
Definition: An interaction-based proof semantics for computation.

Title: Proof Complexity
Definition: A field bounding propositional proofs by resource limitations.

Title: Categorical Logic
Definition: A formal system for reasoning about mathematical structures and their relationships.

Title: Model Theory
Definition: A formal study of how mathematical structures are described by theories.

Title: Computability Theory
Definition: A field of study examining algorithmic problem solvability and its inherent limitations.

Title: Set-Theoretic Metatheory
Definition: An analysis concerning the consistency of axiomatic set theories.

Title: Category-Theoretic Metatheory
Definition: A formal framework for understanding systems through abstract structural relationships.

Title: Type-Theoretic Metatheory
Definition: An exploration of the fundamental rules and reduction processes of abstract systems.

Title: Constructive Metamathematics
Definition: A field of study focusing on computational aspects of mathematical proofs and constructions.

Title: Reverse Mathematics
Definition: A study of the strength of mathematical theorems.

Title: Proof Mining
Definition: A systematic approach to deriving numerical bounds from mathematical proofs.

Title: Topological Dimension
Definition: A measure quantifying the complexity of local or global structure in topological spaces.

Title: Lebesgue Covering Dimension
Definition: A measure of topological complexity based on open-cover refinements.

Title: Extension Dimension
Definition: A minimal extension-complex dimension defining spatial extent.

Title: Correlation Dimension
Definition: A pairwise distance distribution exponent.

Title: Information Dimension
Definition: An entropy-based scaling exponent characterizing data complexity.

Title: Rényi (Generalized) Dimensions
Definition: A spectrum of fractal exponents characterizing a set's scaling behavior.

Title: Conformal Dimension
Definition: A minimal dimension under quasisymmetry.

Title: Ahlfors Regular Conformal Dimension
Definition: A conformal dimension measuring the distortion of geometric objects in Ahlfors-regular spaces.

Title: Lower Dimension
Definition: A measure of how an object or space scales with respect to its geometric properties.

Title: Topological (Lebesgue‐Borel) Dimension
Definition: A geometric property measuring the complexity of a shape's structure.

Title: Capacity Dimension
Definition: A dimension related to capacity or energy integrals.

Title: Small Inductive Dimension
Definition: A boundary-based recursive dimension for topological spaces.

Title: Large Inductive Dimension
Definition: A recursive dimension based on topological separators.

Title: Cohomological Dimension
Definition: A largest nontrivial cohomology degree of a module.

Title: Hausdorff Dimension
Definition: A measure-scaling exponent characterizing the complexity of irregular sets.

Title: Minkowski-Bouligand (Box-Counting) Dimension
Definition: A measure of a fractal's complexity and space-filling capacity.

Title: Packing Dimension
Definition: A measure-based packing exponent that quantifies how densely objects can fill space.

Title: Assouad Dimension
Definition: A measure of the growth rate of the minimum number of balls required to cover a set.

Title: Nagata Dimension
Definition: A metric covering control dimension.

Title: Geometric Structure
Definition: A mathematical abstraction capturing shapes, sizes, and relative positions of figures.

Title: Classical Spaces
Definition: A set of fundamental geometric environments describing spatial relationships.

Title: Incidence & Finite Geometries
Definition: An axiomatic system exploring finite sets of points and lines.

Title: Convex & Discrete Geometry
Definition: A study of geometric shapes, their properties, and arrangements in space.

Title: Noncommutative & Derived Geometry
Definition: A study of spaces using algebraic methods and generalized geometric structures.

Title: Tropical Geometry
Definition: A tropical algebraic geometry studies algebraic varieties using a valuation-theoretic approach.

Title: Synthetic Differential Geometry
Definition: A framework for studying smooth manifolds using intuitionistic logic.

Title: Geometric Probability & Stochastic Geometry
Definition: A study of probability distributions on geometric spaces.

Title: Metric & Normed Structures
Definition: A distance and normed vector spaces define measurements in mathematical spaces.

Title: Manifolds
Definition: A manifold is a space that locally resembles Euclidean space.

Title: Bundles & Group Manifolds
Definition: A mathematical structure describing fibered spaces with group actions.

Title: Algebraic & Complex Varieties
Definition: A set of points satisfying polynomial equations.

Title: Discrete & Combinatorial Complexes
Definition: A framework for organizing discrete geometric objects and their relationships.

Title: Fractals & Self-Similar Sets
Definition: An infinitely repeated geometric pattern that exhibits self-similarity at all scales.

Title: Metric-Geometric Generalizations
Definition: A generalization of geometric concepts focusing on curvature and metric spaces.

Title: Moduli & Parameter Spaces
Definition: A space representing variations of geometric configurations.

Title: Fundamental Concept
Definition: A foundational element from which complex ideas are built.

Title: Set
Definition: A collection of distinct elements considered as a single entity.

Title: Relation
Definition: A subset of a Cartesian product specifying correspondences between elements.

Title: Number
Definition: An abstract representation of quantity, magnitude, or position in a sequence.

Title: Function
Definition: A mapping assigning each element of one set to a unique element of another.

Title: Tuple
Definition: An ordered, finite sequence of elements.

Title: Operation
Definition: A rule for combining elements of sets to produce elements.

Title: Proposition / Predicate
Definition: a statement or condition that may be true or false.

Title: Mathematical Proposition
Definition: A proposition within a formal mathematical system.

Title: Mathematical Theorem
Definition: A demonstrated truth derived from axioms using logical deduction.

Title: Geometric Theorem
Definition: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning geometric figures, spaces, or properties.

Title: Pythagorean Theorem
Definition: A geometric theorem stating that in a right-angled triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the lengths of the other two sides.

Title: Euler's Theorem in Geometry
Definition: A fundamental geometric relationship connecting triangle centers and radii.

Title: Desargues's Theorem
Definition: A theorem in projective geometry concerning two triangles in perspective.

Title: Pappus's Hexagon Theorem
Definition: A theorem in projective geometry concerning the collinearity of intersection points.

Title: Pascal's Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating that three collinear points arise from the intersections of opposite sides of a hexagon inscribed in a conic.

Title: Brianchon's Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating that if a hexagon is circumscribed about a conic section, its main diagonals are concurrent.

Title: Fundamental Theorem of Projective Geometry
Definition: A projectivity is uniquely determined by its action on three collinear points.

Title: Pick's Theorem
Definition: A formula relates the area of a simple polygon with integer lattice vertices to its interior and boundary points.

Title: Gauss-Bonnet Theorem
Definition: A theorem relating a surface's curvature to its topological characteristics.

Title: Cauchy's Rigidity Theorem for Polyhedra
Definition: A theorem stating convex polyhedra with congruent faces are congruent.

Title: Triangle Inequality Theorem
Definition: The sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle must be greater than or equal to the length of the third side.

Title: Thales's Theorem
Definition: An angle inscribed in a semicircle is a right angle.

Title: Exterior Angle Theorem
Definition: An exterior angle of a triangle equals the sum of the two remote interior angles.

Title: Power of a Point Theorem
Definition: For a given point and circle, the product of distances from the point to the intersection points along any secant line is constant.

Title: Simson Line Theorem
Definition: A point on a triangle's circumcircle has perpendiculars to the sides meeting at a single line.

Title: Butterfly Theorem
Definition: A theorem concerning properties of chords and a point on a chord within a circle.

Title: Napoleon's Theorem
Definition: A geometric theorem states that equilateral triangles constructed on the sides of any triangle produce a new equilateral triangle from their centers.

Title: Morley's Trisector Theorem
Definition: A geometric theorem states that the intersection points of adjacent angle trisectors form an equilateral triangle.

Title: Euclid's Theorem on the Infinitude of Primes
Definition: A fundamental proof demonstrating an unending quantity of prime numbers.

Title: Angle Sum Theorem for Triangles
Definition: A geometric theorem states that the interior angles of any triangle sum to 180 degrees.

Title: Pons Asinorum (Isosceles Triangle Theorem)
Definition: A triangle with two equal sides also possesses two equal opposite angles.

Title: Apollonius's Theorem
Definition: A theorem relating a triangle's median length to its side lengths.

Title: Ptolemy's Theorem
Definition: A theorem relating the four sides and two diagonals of a cyclic quadrilateral.

Title: Ceva's Theorem
Definition: A geometric theorem concerning the concurrency of cevians within a triangle.

Title: Menelaus's Theorem
Definition: A theorem about collinear points on a triangle's sides or extensions.

Title: Heron's Formula (as a theorem)
Definition: A theorem stating that the area of a triangle whose sides have lengths \(a, b, c\) is \(\sqrt{s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)}\) where \(s\) is the semi-perimeter. The formula itself is an expression, but the statement that it correctly gives the area is a theorem.

Title: Number-Theoretic Theorem
Definition: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning the properties and relationships of numbers, especially integers.

Title: Euclid's Theorem on the Infinitude of Primes
Definition: A fundamental mathematical proof asserting the endless existence of prime numbers.

Title: Dirichlet's Theorem on Arithmetic Progressions
Definition: States that for any two coprime integers \(a\) and \(d\), there are infinitely many primes of the form \(a + nd\), where \(n\) is a non-negative integer.

Title: Thue-Siegel-Roth Theorem
Definition: A result on Diophantine approximation of algebraic numbers.

Title: Fermat's Last Theorem
Definition: A statement asserting that no positive integers \(a, b, c\) can satisfy \(a^n + b^n = c^n\) for \(n > 2\).

Title: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
Definition: A unique prime factorization exists for every integer greater than one.

Title: Fermat's Little Theorem
Definition: States that if \(p\) is a prime number, then for any integer \(a\) not divisible by \(p\), \(a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\).

Title: Chinese Remainder Theorem
Definition: A theorem providing conditions for a unique solution to simultaneous congruences modulo the product of moduli.

Title: Wilson's Theorem
Definition: A fundamental number theory result relating primality to a factorial congruence.

Title: Euler's Totient Theorem (Fermat-Euler Theorem)
Definition: A statement declaring that if \(n\) and \(a\) are coprime, then \(a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\).

Title: Lagrange's Four-Square Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating every natural number is the sum of four squares.

Title: Quadratic Reciprocity Law
Definition: Relates the solvability of \(x^2 \equiv p \pmod{q}\) to the solvability of \(x^2 \equiv q \pmod{p}\) for distinct odd primes \(p\) and \(q\).

Title: Prime Number Theorem
Definition: A theorem describing the asymptotic distribution of prime numbers.

Title: Algebraic Theorem
Definition: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning algebraic structures and their properties.

Title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
Definition: A theorem stating every non-constant polynomial with complex coefficients has at least one complex root.

Title: Spectral Theorem (Linear Algebra)
Definition: A theorem detailing conditions for a linear operator's diagonalization.

Title: Lagrange's Theorem (Group Theory)
Definition: A theorem stating that a subgroup's order must divide its parent group's order.

Title: Cayley's Theorem
Definition: States that every group is isomorphic to a subgroup of a symmetric group.

Title: Isomorphism Theorems (for groups, rings, modules)
Definition: A set of fundamental results describing structural relationships between algebraic objects.

Title: Sylow Theorems
Definition: A set of theorems concerning the number of subgroups of a prime power order in finite groups.

Title: Hilbert's Basis Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating that if R is a Noetherian ring, then the polynomial ring R[x] is also Noetherian.

Title: Abel-Ruffini Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating no general algebraic solution exists for polynomial equations of degree five or higher.

Title: Galois Theory Main Theorem
Definition: A fundamental result connecting field extensions and group theory.

Title: Rank-Nullity Theorem (Linear Algebra)
Definition: States that for a linear map \(T: V \to W\), the dimension of V is the sum of the dimension of the kernel of T and the dimension of the image of T.

Title: Analytic Theorem
Definition: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning concepts from mathematical analysis, such as limits, continuity, derivatives, integrals, and infinite series.

Title: Intermediate Value Theorem
Definition: States that if a continuous function, \(f\), with an interval, \([a, b]\), as its domain, takes values \(f(a)\) and \(f(b)\) at each end of the interval, then it also takes any value between \(f(a)\) and \(f(b)\) at some point within the interval.

Title: Riemann Mapping Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating that any simply connected open subset of the complex plane, excluding the entire plane, can be conformally mapped to the unit disk.

Title: Dominated Convergence Theorem
Definition: A theorem providing sufficient conditions for swapping limits and integrals of integrable functions.

Title: Inverse Function Theorem
Definition: A theorem providing conditions for a function to be invertible near a specific point and detailing its inverse's derivative.

Title: Calculus Theorem
Definition: A mathematical theorem specifically foundational to or derived within the field of Calculus, concerning concepts such as limits, derivatives, integrals, and series.

Title: Rolle's Theorem
Definition: A special case of the Mean Value Theorem, stating that for a differentiable function taking equal values at two distinct points, there is at least one point between them where the first derivative is zero.

Title: Product Rule Theorem
Definition: A formula to compute the derivative of a product of two functions.

Title: Quotient Rule Theorem
Definition: A formula to compute the derivative of a ratio of two functions.

Title: Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals (Gradient Theorem)
Definition: A line integral through a conservative field equals the difference in potential between the endpoints.

Title: L'Hôpital's Rule
Definition: A method for evaluating limits of indeterminate forms by differentiating numerators and denominators.

Title: Squeeze Theorem (Sandwich Theorem)
Definition: A theorem stating that if two functions bound a third, and the bounding functions meet at a limit, the middle function must also meet that limit.

Title: Weierstrass M-test
Definition: A theorem that provides a sufficient condition for a series of functions to converge uniformly.

Title: Fubini's Theorem
Definition: A theorem providing conditions under which multiple integrals can be computed via iterated integration.

Title: Green's Theorem
Definition: A theorem relating a line integral around a simple closed curve to a double integral over the plane region it encloses.

Title: Stokes' Theorem
Definition: Relates the integral of a curl of a vector field over a surface to the line integral of the vector field over the boundary of the surface.

Title: Divergence Theorem (Gauss's Theorem)
Definition: A fundamental theorem relating the flow of a vector field through a closed surface to the divergence within.

Title: Chain Rule Theorem
Definition: A formula to compute the derivative of a composite function.

Title: Extreme Value Theorem
Definition: States that if a real-valued function \(f\) is continuous on a closed interval \([a, b]\), then \(f\) must attain a maximum and a minimum, each at least once.

Title: Mean Value Theorem
Definition: States that for a differentiable function on an interval, the average rate of change equals the instantaneous rate of change at some point.

Title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
Definition: A theorem relating differentiation and integration as inverse operations.

Title: Taylor's Theorem
Definition: A theorem providing an approximation of a function near a specific point using a polynomial.

Title: Cauchy's Integral Theorem (Complex Analysis)
Definition: A statement asserting that a line integral of a holomorphic function over a closed path within a simply connected domain is zero.

Title: Residue Theorem (Complex Analysis)
Definition: A powerful tool to evaluate line integrals of analytic functions over closed curves; it can often be used to compute real integrals as well.

Title: Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating every bounded sequence in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) has a convergent subsequence.

Title: Heine-Borel Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating that for a subset of Euclidean space, compactness is equivalent to being closed and bounded.

Title: Combinatorial Theorem
Definition: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning the study of finite or countable discrete structures, including enumeration, existence, construction, and optimization.

Title: Pigeonhole Principle
Definition: A statement asserting that if more items than containers exist, at least one container holds multiple items.

Title: Van der Waerden's Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating that any sufficiently large set of integers colored with finitely many colors must contain a monochromatic arithmetic progression.

Title: Ramsey's Theorem
Definition: An assertion that a monochromatic structure must exist within a sufficiently large system with finite coloring.

Title: Hall's Marriage Theorem
Definition: A condition for the existence of a system of distinct representatives for a collection of finite sets.

Title: Dilworth's Theorem
Definition: A theorem relating the minimum number of chains to the largest antichain size.

Title: Sperner's Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating the maximum size of an antichain in a power set.

Title: Turan's Theorem
Definition: A result in extremal graph theory about the maximum number of edges in a graph not containing a complete graph \(K_r\) as a subgraph.

Title: Burnside's Lemma (Orbit-Counting Theorem)
Definition: An equation relating the number of orbits of a group action to the number of fixed points.

Title: Max-Flow Min-Cut Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating that the maximum flow from a source to a sink equals the minimum capacity of a cut.

Title: Four Color Theorem
Definition: States that any map in a plane can be colored using four or fewer colors in such a way that no two adjacent regions have the same color.

Title: Topological Theorem
Definition: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning properties of topological spaces that are invariant under continuous deformations (homeomorphisms).

Title: Brouwer Fixed-Point Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating any continuous map of a compact convex set to itself has a fixed point.

Title: Tychonoff's Theorem
Definition: States that the product of any collection of compact topological spaces is compact with respect to the product topology.

Title: Urysohn's Lemma
Definition: A principle stating that two disjoint closed sets in a normal space can be separated by a continuous function.

Title: Tietze Extension Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating continuous functions on a closed subset of a normal space extend to the entire space.

Title: Baire Category Theorem
Definition: A theorem in topology that describes properties of complete metric spaces and other similar topological spaces.

Title: Jordan Curve Theorem
Definition: A simple closed curve divides a plane into distinct interior and exterior regions.

Title: Hairy Ball Theorem
Definition: States that there is no nonvanishing continuous tangent vector field on an even-dimensional n-sphere.

Title: Seifert-van Kampen Theorem
Definition: Expresses the fundamental group of a topological space \(X\) which is the union of two path-connected open subspaces in terms of the fundamental groups of the subspaces and their intersection.

Title: Classification of Surfaces Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating compact, connected 2-manifolds are homeomorphic to a sphere, tori, or projective planes.

Title: Set-Theoretic Theorem
Definition: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning the properties of sets, often within a specific axiomatic system like ZFC.

Title: Cantor's Theorem
Definition: A statement asserting the power set of any set possesses a strictly greater cardinality.

Title: Schroeder-Bernstein Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating that if two sets have injections into each other, they are equinumerous.

Title: Zorn's Lemma
Definition: A statement asserting that any partially ordered set with upper bounds for all chains has at least one maximal element.

Title: Well-Ordering Theorem
Definition: A principle asserting that any set can be arranged in a specific sequence.

Title: Continuum Hypothesis (Statement as a theorem within models)
Definition: A proposition stating no set cardinality exists strictly between integers and real numbers.

Title: Cantor-Bendixson Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating every closed subset of a Polish space is a perfect set union.

Title: Probabilistic Theorem
Definition: A mathematical theorem primarily concerning the formal study of probability, random variables, and stochastic processes.

Title: Law of Large Numbers (LLN)
Definition: A statistical principle stating sample averages approach expected values with more trials.

Title: Weak Law of Large Numbers
Definition: A fundamental theorem stating sample averages converge to expected values.

Title: Strong Law of Large Numbers
Definition: A theorem stating that the average of a sequence of random variables converges to the expected value.

Title: Central Limit Theorem (CLT)
Definition: A theorem stating that the sum or average of many independent random variables approaches a normal distribution.

Title: Bayes' Theorem
Definition: Describes the probability of an event, based on prior knowledge of conditions that might be related to the event.

Title: Borel-Cantelli Lemmas
Definition: A pair of results in probability theory concerning the convergence of event sequences.

Title: Kolmogorov's Zero-One Law
Definition: A theorem stating that tail events of independent random variables must have probability zero or one.

Title: Martingale Convergence Theorem
Definition: A theorem providing conditions for the convergence of a bounded stochastic process.

Title: Logical Theorem (Metatheorem)
Definition: A mathematical statement concerning properties of formal logical systems.

Title: Gödel's Completeness Theorem (First-Order Logic)
Definition: A statement is provable from axioms if and only if it is true in every model of those axioms.

Title: Gödel's Incompleteness Theorems -
Definition: A foundational result in mathematical logic concerning formal axiomatic systems.

Title: First Incompleteness Theorem
Definition: A statement about formal systems declares that some truths cannot be proven.

Title: Second Incompleteness Theorem
Definition: A formal system cannot prove its own consistency.

Title: Compactness Theorem (First-Order Logic)
Definition: A theorem stating a set of sentences has a model iff every finite subset does.

Title: Löwenheim-Skolem Theorem
Definition: A theorem stating that if a theory has an infinite model, it has models of all infinite cardinalities.

Title: Church-Turing Thesis (as a formal statement within computability theory)
Definition: An assertion defining the limits of what can be computed by any mechanical procedure.

Title: Tarski's Undefinability Theorem
Definition: States that arithmetical truth cannot be defined in arithmetic.

Title: Craig's Interpolation Theorem
Definition: States that if \(\phi \models \psi\) is a valid entailment in first-order logic, then there exists an interpolant sentence \(\chi\) whose non-logical symbols occur in both \(\phi\) and \(\psi\), such that \(\phi \models \chi\) and \(\chi \models \psi\).

Title: Empirical Proposition
Definition: A statement whose truth value is determined by observation, experience, or scientific investigation of the physical or social world.

Title: Scientific Hypothesis
Definition: A proposed explanation for a phenomenon, which can be tested through experimentation or observation.

Title: Scientific Law (Empirical)
Definition: A descriptive generalization about how the natural world behaves under stated circumstances, based on repeated empirical observations.

Title: Normative Proposition
Definition: A statement expressing a value judgment or prescription about what should be.

Title: Ethical Proposition
Definition: A statement concerning moral rightness or wrongness, good or bad, duty or obligation.

Title: Legal Proposition
Definition: A statement within a legal system that prescribes, permits, or prohibits actions, or defines rights and obligations.

Title: Definition
Definition: A statement that explains the meaning of a word, phrase, or concept, often by specifying its essential qualities or properties.

Title: Lexical
Definition: A definition that explains how a term is actually used by speakers of a language.

Title: English Lexical
Definition: A lexical definition for a term as used in the English language.

Title: Mathematical Field/System
Definition: A distinct branch or area of study within mathematics, characterized by a coherent set of concepts, theories, methods, and problems.

Title: Algebra
Definition: A branch of mathematics dealing with symbols and rules for manipulating them.

Title: Elementary Algebra
Definition: A branch of mathematics dealing with symbols and the rules for manipulating them.

Title: Abstract Algebra
Definition: An area of mathematics dealing with algebraic structures and their properties.

Title: Linear Algebra
Definition: A branch of mathematics focused on vectors, matrices, and their operations.

Title: Boolean Algebra
Definition: An abstract algebraic structure that captures the properties of logical operations.

Title: Combinatorics
Definition: A branch of mathematics focused on counting and finite structures.

Title: Set Theory
Definition: A mathematical theory of collections of distinct objects, known as sets.

Title: Category Theory
Definition: A branch of mathematics studying abstract structures and the relationships between them using categories, objects, and morphisms.

Title: Geometry
Definition: A branch of mathematics dealing with shapes, sizes, and positions of figures.

Title: Euclidean Geometry
Definition: A mathematical system describing flat surfaces and spatial relationships without curvature.

Title: Non-Euclidean Geometry
Definition: A geometry where parallel lines can meet or diverge.

Title: Differential Geometry
Definition: A mathematical field studying smooth manifolds and the geometric structures they carry.

Title: Algebraic Geometry
Definition: A mathematical field that studies geometric problems using abstract algebraic techniques.

Title: Topology
Definition: A branch of mathematics concerned with properties preserved under continuous deformation.

Title: General Topology
Definition: A branch of mathematics studying properties of spaces preserved under continuous transformations.

Title: Algebraic Topology
Definition: A branch of mathematics that uses algebraic structures to study topological spaces.

Title: Differential Topology
Definition: A field of mathematics studying smooth manifolds and their properties.

Title: Analysis
Definition: The branch of mathematics dealing with limits and related theories, such as differentiation, integration, measure, infinite series, and analytic functions.

Title: Calculus
Definition: A fundamental branch of mathematics focusing on rates of change and accumulation, built upon the concepts of limits, derivatives, integrals, and infinite series.

Title: Differential Calculus
Definition: A branch of calculus focused on studying how quantities change at varying rates.

Title: Integral Calculus
Definition: The branch of calculus concerned with the study of accumulation of quantities and the areas under curves.

Title: Multivariable Calculus
Definition: An extension of calculus to functions of more than one variable.

Title: Vector Calculus
Definition: A branch of mathematics concerned with differentiation and integration of vector fields.

Title: Real Analysis
Definition: The branch of mathematical analysis dealing with real numbers and real-valued functions of a real variable.

Title: Complex Analysis
Definition: A branch of mathematical analysis exploring functions of complex variables.

Title: Functional Analysis
Definition: A branch of mathematical analysis that studies vector spaces with limit-related structures.

Title: Harmonic Analysis
Definition: A branch of mathematics concerned with the representation of functions or signals as the superposition of basic waves, and the study of and generalization of the concepts of Fourier series and Fourier transforms.

Title: Numerical Analysis
Definition: A study of algorithms that approximate solutions to problems in mathematical analysis.

Title: Number Theory
Definition: A branch of pure mathematics devoted primarily to the study of integers and integer-valued functions.

Title: Elementary Number Theory
Definition: A branch of mathematics focusing on integer properties and relationships.

Title: Analytic Number Theory
Definition: A branch of mathematics that uses analytic methods to study properties of integers.

Title: Algebraic Number Theory
Definition: A branch of mathematics studying algebraic structures related to integers.

Title: Logic (Mathematical)
Definition: A branch of study applying formal logic to mathematical reasoning and mathematical systems.

Title: Probability Theory
Definition: The mathematical framework for quantifying uncertainty and understanding random phenomena.

Title: Statistics (Mathematical)
Definition: A branch of mathematics concerned with data analysis and interpretation.

Title: Discrete Mathematics
Definition: The study of mathematical structures that are fundamentally discrete rather than continuous.

Title: Combinatorial Structure

Definition: A traditional lunisolar calendaring system used by the Cherokee people, tied to the cycles of the moon and solar events, often with month names reflecting agricultural or natural phenomena.

Title: Sidereal Calendar System
Definition: A calendaring system based on the sidereal year, which measures the Earth's orbital period with respect to the fixed stars.

Title: Astronomical Sidereal Calendar
Definition: Calendars used in astronomy based on Earth's true orbital period relative to distant stars, not the sun's apparent position.

Title: Practical/Applied Calendar System
Definition: A calendaring system designed for specific administrative, professional, or specialized temporal organization, not solely dependent on astronomical cycles.

Title: Fiscal Calendar System
Definition: A calendaring system used for business or financial reporting, often not aligned with standard astronomical years (e.g., a fiscal year starting July 1).

Title: Academic Calendar System
Definition: A calendaring system used by educational institutions to schedule terms, semesters, and holidays.

Title: Ecclesiastical Calendar System
Definition: A calendaring system used by religious denominations to organize their liturgical year, feasts, and fasts (e.g., Christian Liturgical Calendar, specific denominational calendars).

Title: Broadcasting Calendar System
Definition: A calendaring system used in media for scheduling television seasons, advertising periods, etc.

Title: Sports League Calendar System
Definition: A calendaring system used by sports organizations to schedule seasons, games, and playoffs.

Title: Geological/Scientific Time Scale
Definition: A hierarchical system of chronological dating that relates geological strata (stratigraphy) to time, used by Earth scientists to describe the timing and relationships of events in Earth history.

Title: International Chronostratigraphic Chart
Definition: The standard global geological time scale, managed by the International Commission on Stratigraphy.

Title: Conceptual/Theoretical Calendar System
Definition: A calendaring system proposed for theoretical or reform purposes, or as a simplified model, not necessarily in wide practical use.

Title: French Republican Calendar
Definition: A solar calendar proposed during the French Revolution, based on a decimal system, though short-lived.

Title: Soviet Revolutionary Calendar
Definition: A calendar used in the Soviet Union for a period, attempting to implement five- or six-day weeks and disrupting traditional cycles.

Title: World Calendar
Definition: A proposed calendar reform designed to be perpetual, with fixed dates for holidays and quarters.

Title: Hanke-Henry Permanent Calendar
Definition: A proposed calendar reform designed to be perpetual, with a regular 364-day year and an extra week every five or six years.

Title: Information Characteristic Type
Definition: An intrinsic or ascribed characteristic, quality, or attribute of information or informational constructs.

Title: Information Assurance Characteristic Type
Definition: Concepts safeguarding information properties.

Title: Confidentiality Characteristic Type
Definition: Information secrecy principle.

Title: Integrity Characteristic Type
Definition: Information trustworthiness principle.

Title: Availability Characteristic Type
Definition: Information accessibility principle.

Title: Authenticity Characteristic Type
Definition: Information genuineness principle.

Title: Non-Repudiation Characteristic Type
Definition: Information action accountability.

Title: Trustworthiness Characteristic Type
Definition: Information system reliance.

Title: Information Pragmatic Characteristic Type
Definition: Aspects of information use/interpretation.

Title: Pragmatic Function Characteristic Type
Definition: Concept of information's purpose.

Title: Contextuality Characteristic Type
Definition: Concept of information context.

Title: Intentionality Characteristic Type
Definition: Concept of information intent.

Title: Feedback Potential Characteristic Type
Definition: Concept of information feedback.

Title: Controllability Characteristic Type
Definition: Concept of information control.

Title: Information Unit Characteristic Type
Definition: A classification of fundamental units used to compose or measure information.

Title: Symbolic Information Unit Characteristic Type
Definition: Type of unit based on symbols (e.g., character, grapheme).

Title: Semantic Information Unit Characteristic Type
Definition: Type of unit based on meaning (e.g., proposition, lexeme).

Title: Quantitative Information Unit Characteristic Type
Definition: Type of unit for measuring information quantity (e.g., bit, nat).

Title: Information Operation (Abstract)
Definition: Abstract actions on information.

Title: Information Transformation Operation (Abstract)
Definition: Abstract data conversion/change.

Title: Information Analysis Operation (Abstract)
Definition: Abstract pattern finding/analysis.

Title: Information Interpretation Operation (Abstract)
Definition: Abstract meaning extraction/decoding.

Title: Information Generation Operation (Abstract)
Definition: Abstract information synthesis/creation.

Title: Information Filtering Operation (Abstract)
Definition: Abstract information selection/reduction.

Title: Physical
Definition: The fundamental domain of tangible reality and its characteristics within space-time

Title: Physical Entity
Definition: discrete objects or continuous existences

Title: Physical Substance
Definition: homogeneous materials

Title: Subatomic Particle
Definition: fundamental constituent of matter and energy.

Title: Fermion
Definition: A kind of elementary particle that are constituents of matter, obey Fermi-Dirac statistics, and have half-integer spin

Title: Quark
Definition: A kind of fermion that experiences the strong interaction and carries fractional electric charge

Title: Lepton
Definition: A kind of fermion that does not experience the strong interaction

Title: Antiquark
Definition: The antiparticle of a quark

Title: Antilepton
Definition: The antiparticle of a lepton

Title: Positron
Definition: (Anti-electron)

Title: Boson
Definition: A kind of elementary particle that are typically force carriers or associated with fundamental fields, obey Bose-Einstein statistics, and have integer spin

Title: Gauge Boson
Definition: A kind of boson that mediates fundamental forces, spin-1

Definition: a

Definition: a

Definition: a

Definition: a

Title: Scalar Boson
Definition: A kind of boson with spin-0

Title: Composite Particle
Definition: A subatomic particle composed of two or more elementary particles bound together by fundamental forces.

Title: Hadron
Definition: A composite particle that interacts via the strong nuclear force, composed of quarks and/or antiquarks, and gluons.

Title: Baryon
Definition: A type of hadron which is a fermion, typically composed of three quarks (qqq) or three antiquarks (antibaryon, \(\bar{q}\bar{q}\bar{q}\)).

Title: Nucleon
Definition: A baryon that is a primary constituent of atomic nuclei.

Title: Proton
Definition: A stable nucleon with a positive electric charge, composed of two up quarks and one down quark (uud).

Title: Neutron
Definition: A nucleon with no net electric charge, composed of one up quark and two down quarks (udd); stable within nuclei but decays when free.

Title: Hyperon
Definition: A baryon containing one or more strange quarks, but no charm, bottom, or top quarks; typically heavier than nucleons.

Title: Lambda Baryon (\(\Lambda\))
Definition: A hyperon with isospin 0 (e.g., \(\Lambda^0\) (uds)).

Title: Sigma Baryon (\(\Sigma\))
Definition: A hyperon with isospin 1 (e.g., \(\Sigma^+\) (uus), \(\Sigma^0\) (uds), \(\Sigma^-\) (dds)).

Title: Xi Baryon (\(\Xi\))
Definition: A hyperon containing two strange quarks (e.g., \(\Xi^0\) (uss), \(\Xi^-\) (dss)).

Title: Omega Baryon (\(\Omega\))
Definition: A hyperon containing three strange quarks (e.g., \(\Omega^-\) (sss)).

Title: Charmed Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing one or more charm quarks.

Title: Singly Charmed Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing one charm quark (e.g., \(\Lambda_c^+\) (udc), \(\Sigma_c\) (uuc, udc, ddc), \(\Xi_c\) (usc, dsc), \(\Omega_c^0\) (ssc)).

Title: Doubly Charmed Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing two charm quarks (e.g., \(\Xi_{cc}^{++}\) (ccu), \(\Xi_{cc}^{+}\) (ccd)).

Title: Triply Charmed Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing three charm quarks (e.g., \(\Omega_{ccc}^{++}\) (ccc)).

Title: Bottom Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing one or more bottom quarks.

Title: Singly Bottom Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing one bottom quark (e.g., \(\Lambda_b^0\) (udb), \(\Sigma_b\) (uub, udb, ddb), \(\Xi_b\) (usb, dsb), \(\Omega_b^-\) (ssb)).

Title: Doubly Bottom Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing two bottom quarks (e.g., \(\Xi_{bb}^{0}\) (bbu), \(\Xi_{bb}^{-}\) (bbd)).

Title: Triply Bottom Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing three bottom quarks (e.g., \(\Omega_{bbb}^-\) (bbb), hypothetical).

Title: Mixed Heavy Flavor Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing a combination of charm and bottom quarks.

Title: Charm-Bottom Baryon
Definition: A baryon containing one charm quark and one bottom quark (e.g., \(\Xi_{bc}\) (ucb, dcb), \(\Omega_{bc}\) (scb)).

Title: Charm-Charm-Bottom Baryon
Definition: A baryon with two charm quarks and one bottom quark (e.g., \(\Omega_{ccb}\)).

Title: Charm-Bottom-Bottom Baryon
Definition: A baryon with one charm quark and two bottom quarks (e.g., \(\Omega_{cbb}\)).

Title: Antibaryon
Definition: The antiparticle of a baryon, composed of three antiquarks.

Title: Antinucleon
Definition: The antiparticle of a nucleon.

Title: Antiproton (\(\bar{p}\))
Definition: The antiparticle of a proton ( \(\bar{u}\bar{u}\bar{d}\) ).

Title: Antineutron (\(\bar{n}\))
Definition: The antiparticle of a neutron ( \(\bar{u}\bar{d}\bar{d}\) ).

Title: Antihyperon
Definition: The antiparticle of a hyperon (e.g., \(\bar{\Lambda}^0\), \(\bar{\Sigma}^+\), \(\bar{\Xi}^0\), \(\bar{\Omega}^+\)).

Title: Meson
Definition: A type of hadron which is a boson, typically composed of one quark and one antiquark (q\(\bar{q}\)).

Title: Light Meson
Definition: A meson composed of up, down, and/or strange quarks and antiquarks.

Title: Pion (\(\pi\))
Definition: The lightest type of meson (e.g., \(\pi^+\) (u\(\bar{d}\)), \(\pi^0\), \(\pi^-\) (d\(\bar{u}\))).

Title: Kaon (K)
Definition: A meson containing one strange quark or antiquark (e.g., \(K^+\) (u\(\bar{s}\)), \(K^0\) (d\(\bar{s}\))).

Title: Eta Meson (\(\eta, \eta'\))
Definition: Flavor-neutral light mesons (e.g., \(\eta\), \(\eta'(958)\)).

Title: Rho Meson (\(\rho\))
Definition: A short-lived vector meson (e.g., \(\rho(770)\)).

Title: Omega Meson (\(\omega\))
Definition: A short-lived, unflavored vector meson, distinct from the Omega baryon (e.g., \(\omega(782)\)).

Title: Phi Meson (\(\phi\))
Definition: A vector meson consisting primarily of a strange quark and strange antiquark pair (s\(\bar{s}\)) (e.g., \(\phi(1020)\)).

Title: Other Light Meson Family
Definition: Other light mesons often categorized by their spin, parity, and C-parity, such as f-mesons, a-mesons, and K* (vector kaon) mesons.

Title: Heavy Quarkonium
Definition: A flavorless meson composed of a heavy quark and its own antiquark.

Title: Charmonium (c\(\bar{c}\))
Definition: A meson made of a charm quark and a charm antiquark (e.g., J/\(\psi\), \(\psi(2S)\), \(\chi_c\)).

Title: Bottomonium (b\(\bar{b}\))
Definition: A meson made of a bottom quark and a bottom antiquark (e.g., \(\Upsilon(1S)\), \(\Upsilon(2S)\), \(\chi_b\)).

Title: Heavy Flavor Meson (Open Flavor)
Definition: A meson composed of one heavy quark (charm or bottom) and one lighter antiquark, or vice versa.

Title: Charmed Meson (Open Charm)
Definition: A meson containing one charm quark or antiquark, and a lighter antiquark or quark (e.g., D\(^0\) (c\(\bar{u}\)), D\(^+\) (c\(\bar{d}\)), D_s\(^+\) (c\(\bar{s}\)), D* mesons).

Title: Bottom Meson (Open Bottom)
Definition: A meson containing one bottom quark or antiquark, and a lighter antiquark or quark (e.g., B\(^0\) (d\(\bar{b}\)), B\(^+\) (u\(\bar{b}\)), B_s\(^0\) (s\(\bar{b}\)), B* mesons).

Title: Bc Meson
Definition: A meson composed of a bottom quark and a charm antiquark (b\(\bar{c}\)) or a charm quark and a bottom antiquark (c\(\bar{b}\)) (e.g., B_c\(^+\)).

Title: Exotic Hadron
Definition: A hadron that does not fit the traditional model of baryons (three quarks) or mesons (quark-antiquark).

Title: Tetraquark
Definition: An exotic meson composed of four quarks (typically two quarks and two antiquarks: qqq̄q̄).

Title: Pentaquark
Definition: An exotic baryon composed of five quarks (typically four quarks and one antiquark: qqqqq̄).

Title: Glueball
Definition: A hypothetical hadron composed primarily of gluons, with no valence quarks.

Title: Hybrid Hadron
Definition: A hypothetical hadron containing valence quarks/antiquarks and one or more excited gluons.

Title: Atomic Nucleus
Definition: A composite subatomic particle forming the core of an atom, typically composed of one or more protons and zero or more neutrons (collectively called nucleons), bound together by the residual strong force (nuclear force).

Title: Protium Nucleus
Definition: The nucleus of the most common isotope of hydrogen (\(^1\)H), consisting of a single proton. (This is the proton, in its role as a nucleus).

Title: Unstable Atomic Nucleus (Radionuclide) (Property Based Category)
Definition: An atomic nucleus that undergoes radioactive decay, transforming into another nuclide.

Title: Exotic Atomic Nucleus (Composition/Structure Based Category)
Definition: An atomic nucleus with an unusual proton-to-neutron ratio, structure, or composition compared to stable nuclei.

Title: Hypernucleus
Definition: An atomic nucleus that contains at least one hyperon in addition to nucleons.

Title: Halo Nucleus
Definition: An atomic nucleus with a compact core and one or more loosely bound nucleons forming a diffuse "halo" at a relatively large distance.

Title: Superheavy Element Nucleus
Definition: The nucleus of a superheavy element, typically with atomic number Z > 104, often characterized by short half-lives and unique decay modes.

Title: Deuteron
Definition: The nucleus of deuterium (\(^2\)H), an isotope of hydrogen, composed of one proton and one neutron.

Title: Triton
Definition: The nucleus of tritium (\(^3\)H), an isotope of hydrogen, composed of one proton and two neutrons.

Title: Helion (Helium-3 Nucleus)
Definition: The nucleus of the helium-3 isotope (\(^3\)He), composed of two protons and one neutron.

Title: Alpha Particle (Helium-4 Nucleus)
Definition: The nucleus of the helium-4 isotope (\(^4\)He), composed of two protons and two neutrons.

Title: Light Atomic Nucleus (General Category)
Definition: An atomic nucleus with a relatively small number of nucleons (e.g., mass number A < 20), often characterized by specific stability properties.

Title: Medium-Mass Atomic Nucleus (General Category)
Definition: An atomic nucleus with an intermediate number of nucleons (e.g., approximately 20 \(\le\) A \(\le\) 100).

Title: Heavy Atomic Nucleus (General Category)
Definition: An atomic nucleus with a large number of nucleons (e.g., A > 100).

Title: Stable Atomic Nucleus (Property Based Category)
Definition: An atomic nucleus that does not undergo radioactive decay, or decays with an extremely long half-life.

Title: Atom
Definition: smallest unit of a chemical element.

Title: Molecule
Definition: group of atoms bonded together.

Title: Bulk Phase
Definition: macroscopic state of matter with uniform properties.

Title: Solid
Definition: retains a fixed shape and volume.

Title: Crystalline Solid
Definition: A solid in which the atoms, ions, or molecules are arranged in a highly ordered, repeating three-dimensional pattern (a crystal lattice). They have a sharp, well-defined melting point.

Title: Amorphous Solid
Definition: A solid in which the atoms, ions, or molecules are not arranged in a regular, repeating pattern. They lack long-range order and tend to soften over a range of temperatures rather than having a sharp melting point.

Title: Quasicrystal
Definition: A solid with an ordered but non-periodic atomic structure. They exhibit rotational symmetries forbidden to true crystals (e.g., five-fold symmetry).

Title: Liquid Crystal
Definition: A state of matter that has properties between those of a conventional liquid and a solid crystal. It can flow like a liquid but has some degree of long-range orientational order of its molecules, giving it anisotropic (direction-dependent) properties.

Title: Liquid
Definition: takes shape of container; fixed volume.

Title: Newtonian Fluid
Definition: A fluid whose viscosity (resistance to flow) remains constant, regardless of the shear stress applied. Its flow behavior is described by a linear relationship between shear stress and shear rate.

Title: Non-Newtonian Fluid
Definition: A fluid whose viscosity changes depending on the applied shear stress or shear rate. Their flow behavior is more complex and cannot be described by a single constant viscosity.

Title: Superfluid
Definition: A quantum state of matter that exhibits frictionless flow, meaning it can flow indefinitely without losing kinetic energy. It occurs at extremely low temperatures.

Title: Gas
Definition: takes shape and volume of container.

Title: Ideal Gas
Definition: A theoretical gas composed of randomly moving point particles that do not interact with each other except for perfectly elastic collisions. It obeys the ideal gas law. Used as a simplified model for real gases.

Title: Real Gas
Definition: A gas whose molecules occupy volume and interact with each other through attractive and repulsive forces. Their behavior deviates from ideal gas behavior, especially at high pressures and low temperatures.

Title: Plasma
Definition: ionized gas with collective behavior.

Title: Thermal Plasma
Definition: A plasma where the electrons and heavy particles (ions and neutral atoms) are in thermal equilibrium, meaning they have roughly the same temperature.

Title: Non-Thermal Plasma (Cold Plasma)
Definition: A plasma where the electrons are at a much higher temperature than the heavy particles. This allows for plasma effects at lower overall gas temperatures, making it useful for sensitive applications.

Title: Space Plasma (Astrophysical Plasma)
Definition: Plasma that exists in various forms throughout space, from stellar interiors to the interstellar medium, solar wind, and planetary magnetospheres. It typically involves complex magnetic fields.

Title: Composite Material
Definition: made from two or more constituent materials.

Title: Physical Object
Definition: bounded collections of substances

Title: Natural Object
Definition: exists independently of human creation.

Title: Biological Organism
Definition: a living physical entity. Phylogenetic Classification

Title: Bacteria
Definition: These are prokaryotic organisms that represent one of the oldest and most diverse groups of life.

Title: Pseudomonadota (formerly Proteobacteria)
Definition: A highly diverse and ecologically significant phylum, encompassing a wide range of metabolic types. Many well-known bacteria, including many pathogens (e.g., E. coli, Salmonella) and environmental microbes, belong here.

Title: Thermotogota (formerly Thermotogae)
Definition: Primarily hyperthermophilic and anaerobic bacteria, often found in hot springs and marine hydrothermal vents. They are characterized by a unique "toga-like" outer membrane.

Title: Aquificota (formerly Aquificae)
Definition: Considered among the earliest diverging bacterial lineages, these are highly thermophilic and chemolithoautotrophic bacteria, often found in hot springs and hydrothermal vents, deriving energy from inorganic compounds.

Title: Planctomycetota (formerly Planctomycetes)
Definition: A phylogenetically distinct group known for unique cell biology, including the absence of peptidoglycan in cell walls and, for some, internal membrane-bound compartments (e.g., Anammox bacteria that perform anaerobic ammonium oxidation).

Title: Acidobacteriota (formerly Acidobacteria)
Definition: A widespread and diverse phylum, particularly abundant in soils and other terrestrial environments, known for their metabolic versatility and often adaptation to acidic conditions.

Title: Verrucomicrobiota (formerly Verrucomicrobia)
Definition: A morphologically and metabolically diverse phylum found in various environments, including soils, aquatic habitats, and as symbionts. Some members possess unique wart-like cell appendages.

Title: Bacillota (formerly Firmicutes)
Definition: Characterized by a typically Gram-positive cell wall structure, this phylum includes many species important in medicine (pathogens like Staphylococcus, probiotics like Lactobacillus) and industry (fermentation).

Title: Actinomycetota (formerly Actinobacteria)
Definition: Another major Gram-positive phylum, known for complex life cycles, abundant antibiotic production (e.g., Streptomyces), and significant roles in soil decomposition and nutrient cycling. Includes Mycobacterium.

Title: Bacteroidota (formerly Bacteroidetes)
Definition: Abundant in the gut microbiota of animals, including humans, and diverse in environmental niches. Many members are obligate anaerobes and important for carbohydrate fermentation.

Title: Cyanobacteria
Definition: Photosynthetic bacteria, often called "blue-green algae." They perform oxygenic photosynthesis and were crucial in oxygenating Earth's early atmosphere, forming the base of many aquatic food webs.

Title: Spirochaetota (formerly Spirochaetes)
Definition: Characterized by their unique spiral shape and corkscrew-like motility due to internal flagella (endoflagella). Includes important human pathogens like Treponema pallidum (syphilis) and Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease).

Title: Chloroflexota (formerly Chloroflexi)
Definition: A metabolically versatile phylum, including green non-sulfur bacteria (anoxygenic phototrophs) and many thermophilic species found in hot springs; they exhibit diverse morphologies and carbon metabolisms.

Title: Chlorobiota (formerly Chlorobi)
Definition: Known as green sulfur bacteria, these are obligate anaerobic photoautotrophs that perform anoxygenic photosynthesis using bacteriochlorophylls and sulfur compounds as electron donors.

Title: Deinococcota (formerly Deinococcus-Thermus)
Definition: A phylum famous for its members' extreme resistance to radiation (e.g., Deinococcus radiodurans) and high temperatures (e.g., Thermus aquaticus, source of Taq polymerase).

Title: Archaea
Definition: Archaea are prokaryotic organisms. However, phylogenetic studies revealed that they are evolutionarily distinct from Bacteria and, are more closely related to Eukarya than to Bacteria

Title: Euryarchaeota
Definition: This is one of the largest and most diverse archaeal phyla, encompassing a wide range of metabolic types and ecological niches. It includes the well-known methanogens (methane producers), halophiles (salt-lovers), and some thermophiles (heat-lovers).

Title: Crenarchaeota
Definition: Traditionally recognized as another large archaeal phylum, it primarily includes thermophilic (heat-loving) and acidophilic (acid-loving) organisms often found in extreme environments like hot springs and hydrothermal vents.

Title: Thaumarchaeota
Definition: A widely distributed phylum that gained recognition for its abundance in marine and terrestrial environments, particularly for its role in the global nitrogen cycle as ammonia-oxidizing archaea (AOA).

Title: Korarchaeota
Definition: A relatively small phylum primarily identified from environmental DNA sequences (initially from hot springs). Its members are often considered to be deeply branching and sometimes thought to represent an ancient lineage.

Title: Nanoarchaeota
Definition: A unique phylum characterized by extremely small cell sizes and often existing as obligate symbionts or parasites of other archaea (e.g., Nanoarchaeum equitans growing on Ignicoccus hospitilis).

Title: Eukarya
Definition: This domain includes all organisms whose cells have a true nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles.

Title: Archaeplastida
Definition: This supergroup includes all organisms descended from the ancient endosymbiotic event where a heterotrophic eukaryote engulfed a cyanobacterium, leading to the evolution of chloroplasts. It encompasses land plants, red algae, and green algae.

Title: Glaucophyta (Glaucophytes)
Definition: A small, ancient phylum of unicellular freshwater algae, considered the most basal group within Archaeplastida. They are unique for retaining peptidoglycan in their chloroplast outer membrane (called cyanelles), a remnant of their cyanobacterial endosymbiont.

Title: Rhodophyta (Red Algae)
Definition: A large and ancient phylum of primarily multicellular marine algae. They are characterized by accessory photosynthetic pigments (phycoerythrins and phycocyanins) that give them their red color, allowing them to absorb blue light at greater depths.

Title: Viridiplantae (Green Plants / Chloroplastida)
Definition: This large clade includes all green algae and all land plants. They are characterized by having chlorophyll a and b, storing starch as their food reserve, and having cell walls made of cellulose. This is the lineage that gave rise to all terrestrial vegetation.

Title: SAR Supergroup (Stramenopiles, Alveolates, Rhizarians)
Definition: A vast and diverse supergroup unified by molecular phylogenetic data, although morphologically disparate.

Title: Amoebozoa
Definition: Characterized by the presence of lobe-shaped pseudopods used for movement and feeding. This group includes true amoebas, slime molds (both cellular and plasmodial), and some parasitic forms.

Title: Opisthokonta
Definition: This supergroup includes both Animals and Fungi, as well as their closest protistan relatives (e.g., choanoflagellates). A key unifying feature is the presence of a posterior flagellum in motile cells (like sperm).

Title: Excavata
Definition: A diverse supergroup often characterized by a feeding groove ("excavated" appearance) on one side of the cell, and sometimes unusual mitochondria or multiple flagella. Includes many free-living, symbiotic, and parasitic forms.

Title: Cryptista
Definition: A group of mostly unicellular flagellates, many of which are photosynthetic (cryptophytes) due to a secondary endosymbiosis event. Their precise placement relative to other supergroups has been debated but they are increasingly recognized as a distinct basal lineage.

Title: Haptista
Definition: A diverse supergroup of mostly unicellular algae, well-known for haptophytes (which include coccolithophores, key primary producers in oceans) and centrohelids. They often have a unique appendage called a haptonema.

Title: Astronomical Body
Definition: a naturally occurring physical entity in space.

Title: Star
Definition: A massive, luminous sphere of plasma held together by its own gravity. It generates energy through nuclear fusion in its core, primarily converting hydrogen to helium.

Title: Main Sequence Star
Definition: A star that is actively fusing hydrogen into helium in its core. This is the longest and most stable phase of a star's life, and about 90% of all stars, including our Sun, are in this stage. They vary widely in mass, temperature, and luminosity (from hot, blue O-type stars to cool, red M-type stars).

Title: Red Giant
Definition: An evolved star that has exhausted the hydrogen fuel in its core and begun fusing hydrogen in a shell around a helium core. This causes its outer layers to expand significantly and cool, giving it a reddish hue and increased luminosity.

Title: Red Supergiant
Definition: A very massive, evolved star (much more massive than the Sun) that has exhausted hydrogen in its core and expanded to an enormous size, becoming one of the largest stars by volume. They are typically cool and very luminous.

Title: Blue Supergiant / Hypergiant
Definition: Extremely hot, massive, and luminous stars. Blue supergiants are typically massive main-sequence stars that have evolved slightly, while hypergiants are even more luminous and unstable, pushing the theoretical limits of stellar brightness. Both are very rare and have very short lifespans.

Title: White Dwarf
Definition: The dense, hot core remnant of a low to intermediate-mass star (like our Sun) after it has shed its outer layers. It no longer undergoes fusion and slowly cools over billions of years.

Title: Neutron Star
Definition: The extremely dense remnant core of a massive star that has undergone a supernova explosion. It is composed almost entirely of neutrons, packed together incredibly tightly. Some rapidly rotating neutron stars are observed as pulsars.

Title: Brown Dwarf
Definition: A celestial object that is larger than a planet but not massive enough to sustain stable hydrogen fusion in its core, which is the defining characteristic of a true star. They can briefly fuse deuterium. Often called "failed stars."

Title: Protostar
Definition: A very young star that is still gathering mass from its parent molecular cloud. This is the earliest stage of stellar evolution before nuclear fusion begins.

Title: Planet
Definition: A celestial body that orbits a star or stellar remnant, is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, but is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighboring region of planetesimals.

Title: Rocky Planet
Definition: A planet composed primarily of silicate rocks or metals, with a solid surface. They are typically smaller than gas giants and have relatively high densities.

Title: Gas Giant
Definition: A massive planet composed mainly of hydrogen and helium, with a relatively small rocky or metallic core (if any) surrounded by a deep atmosphere of gases. They lack a well-defined solid surface.

Title: Ice Giant
Definition: A large planet primarily composed of heavier elements than hydrogen and helium, such as oxygen, carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur. These elements are typically found in the form of "ices" (volatiles) under high pressure. They have a distinct interior structure from gas giants.

Title: Super-Earth
Definition: An planet with a mass greater than Earth's but substantially less than that of the Solar System's ice giants (Uranus and Neptune). Their composition can vary, ranging from rocky to icy-rocky.

Title: Mini-Neptune (or Sub-Neptune)
Definition: An planet that is smaller than Neptune but larger than a Super-Earth, likely with a significant hydrogen-helium atmosphere enveloping a rocky/icy core. They are not found in our Solar System.

Title: Orphan Planet (or Rogue Planet/Free-Floating Planet)
Definition: A planetary-mass object that has been ejected from its stellar system and orbits the galactic center directly, rather than orbiting a star. While they don't orbit a star, they meet the other criteria for a planet (mass, self-gravity leading to sphericity, no fusion).

Title: Dwarf Planet
Definition: A celestial body that orbits a star or stellar remnant, is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, but has not cleared its neighboring region of other objects.

Title: Natural Satellite (Moon)
Definition: A celestial body that orbits a planet, dwarf planet, or minor planet.

Title: Minor Planet
Definition: An astronomical object in orbit around a star that is neither a planet nor exclusively a comet, including asteroids, centaurs, and trans-Neptunian objects.

Title: Regular Moon
Definition: A moon that typically formed in situ from the same circumplanetary disk of gas and dust that surrounded its parent body. These moons generally have near-circular, prograde (orbiting in the same direction as the parent planet's rotation), and low-inclination orbits. They tend to be larger, more spherical, and can exhibit significant geological activity.

Title: Emotion
Definition: A relatively brief, intense, and often specific affective state, typically involving physiological arousal, expressive behaviors, and conscious experience, often triggered by a particular internal or external stimulus or event.

Title: Joy
Definition: An emotion characterized by intense feelings of elation, pleasure, or delight, often in response to a specific positive event or realization.

Title: Love (Emotional State)
Definition: A complex emotion characterized by deep affection, care, attachment, and often intimacy towards another being or entity. (Distinguished from love as a broader sentiment or relationship construct).

Title: Shame
Definition: A self-conscious emotion characterized by painful feelings of humiliation or distress caused by the consciousness of wrong or foolish behavior, or a perceived inadequacy.

Title: Guilt
Definition: A self-conscious emotion characterized by feelings of culpability or remorse for a perceived offense, transgression, or wrongdoing.

Title: Pride
Definition: A self-conscious emotion characterized by feelings of deep pleasure or satisfaction derived from one's own achievements, qualities, or possessions, or those of someone with whom one is closely associated.

Title: Contempt
Definition: An emotion characterized by feelings of disdain, scorn, or disrespect for someone or something regarded as worthless or inferior.

Title: Gratitude
Definition: An emotion characterized by feelings of thankfulness and appreciation in response to receiving a benefit from another.

Title: Hope
Definition: An emotion characterized by an expectation and desire for a certain positive outcome.

Title: Jealousy
Definition: A complex emotion characterized by feelings of insecurity, fear, and concern over an anticipated loss of something of personal value, particularly in the context of a human relationship.

Title: Envy
Definition: An emotion characterized by a painful or resentful awareness of an advantage enjoyed by another, coupled with a desire to possess the same advantage.

Title: Frustration
Definition: An emotion experienced when an anticipated goal or action is blocked or prevented.

Title: Happiness
Definition: An emotion characterized by a more general and sustained state of contentment, satisfaction, and positive well-being.

Title: Relief
Definition: An emotion experienced upon the removal of distress, pain, or anxiety.

Title: Regret
Definition: An emotion characterized by sadness, repentance, or disappointment over something that has happened or been done, especially a loss or missed opportunity.

Title: Awe
Definition: An emotion characterized by feelings of reverential respect mixed with fear or wonder, often elicited by something perceived as vast, sublime, or powerful.

Title: Amusement
Definition: An emotion characterized by finding something funny or entertaining, often accompanied by smiling or laughter.

Title: Excitement
Definition: An emotion characterized by feelings of great enthusiasm and eagerness.

Title: Contentment
Definition: An emotion characterized by a state of peaceful satisfaction and ease.

Title: Compassion
Definition: An emotion characterized by a deep awareness of and empathy for the suffering of another, coupled with a strong motivation to alleviate that suffering.

Title: Sympathy
Definition: An emotion characterized by feelings of concern, care, and understanding for someone else's sorrow or misfortune, acknowledging their distress.

Title: Sadness
Definition: An emotion characterized by feelings of loss, disadvantage, sorrow, or helplessness.

Title: Anger
Definition: An emotion characterized by feelings of displeasure, antagonism, or hostility, often resulting from perceived provocation, hurt, or threat.

Title: Fear
Definition: An emotion characterized by feelings of apprehension, dread, or alarm, typically triggered by perceived danger or threat.

Title: Surprise
Definition: An emotion characterized by a brief state of astonishment or wonder, typically elicited by an unexpected event.

Title: Disgust
Definition: An emotion characterized by feelings of revulsion or strong disapproval, often in response to something offensive, distasteful, or contaminating.

Title: Interest
Definition: An emotion characterized by a feeling of engagement, focused attention, and concern towards a stimulus or subject, often due to its perceived relevance or importance.

Title: Curiosity
Definition: An emotion characterized by a strong desire to know, learn, or explore something new, unknown, or intriguing, often motivating investigation.

Title: Mood
Definition: A prolonged, less intense, and more diffuse affective state that is not necessarily tied to a specific object or event, often coloring one's overall subjective experience and outlook for a period.

Title: Euthymic Mood
Definition: A relatively stable mood state characterized by a sense of normalcy, calmness, and absence of marked elevation or depression. (Baseline mood).

Title: Tense Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by feelings of mental or nervous strain, stress, or suspense.

Title: Stressed Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by feelings of pressure, demandingness, or being overwhelmed by circumstances.

Title: Nervous Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by unease or apprehension, often accompanied by physical signs of anxiety.

Title: Energetic Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by having or showing great activity or vitality.

Title: Enthusiastic Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by intense and eager enjoyment, interest, or approval.

Title: Vigorous Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by physical or mental strength, health, and energy.

Title: Fatigued Mood / Lethargic Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a lack of energy and enthusiasm, weariness, or sluggishness.

Title: Drained Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by feeling completely exhausted or devoid of energy.

Title: Sluggish Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by feeling noticeably slow, lacking in energy or alertness.

Title: Elevated Mood / Euphoric Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by an exaggerated feeling of well-being, elation, or happiness, often disproportionate to circumstances.

Title: Elated Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by intense happiness, joy, or high spirits, often slightly less extreme or enduring than full euphoria.

Title: Exuberant Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by energetic enthusiasm, vivacity, and lively expression.

Title: Hypomanic Mood
Definition: A persistent, pervasive, and often disruptive elevated, expansive, or irritable mood that is less severe than full mania, typically without significant functional impairment or psychotic features.

Title: Manic Mood
Definition: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, and abnormally and persistently increased goal-directed activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day.

Title: Dysphoric Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by general feelings of unease, dissatisfaction, unhappiness, or sadness.

Title: Uneasy Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by general discomfort, restlessness, or a feeling that something is wrong, without a clear cause.

Title: Dissatisfied Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a general sense of disappointment or unfulfillment.

Title: Pessimistic Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a tendency to expect the worst possible outcome or to dwell on the negative aspects of a situation.

Title: Depressed Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, emptiness, hopelessness, or loss of interest or pleasure. (Can be a symptom of a disorder or a standalone mood state).

Title: Anhedonic Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a significant loss of interest or pleasure in activities that were once considered enjoyable.

Title: Melancholic Mood
Definition: A severe form of depressed mood characterized by distinct quality of mood, profound despair, psychomotor retardation or agitation, and other specific somatic symptoms (often a specifier in clinical depression).

Title: Apathetic-Depressed Mood
Definition: Depressed mood combined with a predominant lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.

Title: Irritable Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a propensity to be easily annoyed, angered, or agitated.

Title: Agitated-Irritable Mood
Definition: Irritable mood accompanied by increased psychomotor activity, restlessness, or inner tension.

Title: Hostile Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by feelings of antagonism or unfriendliness, often expressed through aggressive behavior or thoughts.

Title: Anxious Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by sustained feelings of apprehension, worry, nervousness, or unease, often about an impending event or something with an uncertain outcome.

Title: Generalized Anxious Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by pervasive, non-specific worry and apprehension about a variety of things.

Title: Apprehensive Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a specific anticipation of impending danger, misfortune, or unpleasantness.

Title: Panicked Mood
Definition: A sudden, intense mood characterized by overwhelming fear, terror, or dread, often accompanied by physical symptoms.

Title: Apathetic Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern; indifference.

Title: Indifferent Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a lack of interest or concern, often more neutral than true apathy.

Title: Listless Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a lack of energy, enthusiasm, or spirit; sluggishness.

Title: Expansive Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by unceasing and indiscriminate enthusiasm for interpersonal, sexual, or occupational interactions, often associated with an overestimation of one's importance or capabilities.

Title: Calm Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by tranquility, serenity, and freedom from agitation or disturbance.

Title: Relaxed Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a state of being free from tension and anxiety.

Title: Peaceful Mood
Definition: A mood characterized by a sense of inner quiet and freedom from disturbance.

Title: Color Perception
