Title: Form Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of shapes, outlines, and spatial arrangements of objects.

Title: Motion Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of movement or changes in position.

Title: Light Intensity Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of brightness or dimness.

Title: Auditory Sensation
Definition: subjective experience from sound input.

Title: Pitch Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of how high or low a sound is, related to frequency.

Title: Loudness Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of the intensity or volume of a sound, related to amplitude.

Title: Timbre Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of the quality or character of a sound that distinguishes different types of sound production (e.g., musical instruments, voices).

Title: Spatial Audition
Definition: the subjective experience of where a sound originates in space.

Title: Olfactory Sensation
Definition: subjective experience from smell input.

Title: Odor Quality Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of distinct types of smells.

Title: Odor Intensity Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of the strength or concentration of a smell.

Title: Gustatory Sensation
Definition: subjective experience from taste input.

Title: Basic Taste Qualities
Definition: the subjective experience of the fundamental tastes recognized by the tongue.

Title: Flavor Perception
Definition: the complex subjective experience resulting from the combination of taste, smell (through retronasal olfaction), and often touch (texture) and temperature in the mouth.

Title: Somatosensory Sensation
Definition: subjective experience from bodily senses (touch, pain, temperature, proprioception, kinesthesia).

Title: Tactile Perception (Touch)
Definition: the subjective experience of pressure, vibration, texture, or contact on the skin.

Title: Nociception (Pain Perception)
Definition: the subjective experience of discomfort or unpleasant sensations arising from tissue damage or potential damage.

Title: Thermoception (Temperature Perception)
Definition: the subjective experience of heat or cold on the skin or internally.

Title: Proprioception
Definition: the subjective experience of the relative position of one's own body parts and strength of effort being used in movement, derived from internal receptors.

Title: Kinesthesia
Definition: the subjective experience of movement of body parts.

Title: Vestibular Sensation
Definition: subjective experience from balance/orientation system.

Title: Balance Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of maintaining equilibrium and spatial stability.

Title: Head Position/Movement Perception
Definition: the subjective experience of the orientation and acceleration of the head in space.

Title: Interoceptive Sensation
Definition: subjective experience of internal bodily states.

Title: Visceral Sensation
Definition: the subjective experience of internal organ states.

Title: Bodily Homeostasis Perception
Definition: the subjective experience related to the body's internal regulatory processes.

Title: Mental Process
Definition: an operation or sequence of changes occurring in the mind

Title: Cognitive Process
Definition: a mental operation involved in acquiring, processing, or using knowledge and information

Title: Perceptual Process
Definition: interpreting sensory information.

Title: Social Cognitive Process
Definition: a cognitive process involved in understanding and interacting with the social world

Title: Theory of Mind
Definition: understanding others' mental states.

Title: Empathy (as a cognitive process component)
Definition: cognitively understanding others' feelings.

Title: Social Attribution Process
Definition: explaining others' behavior.

Title: Stereotyping Process
Definition: applying generalized beliefs to groups.

Title: Attentional Process
Definition: selecting and focusing on stimuli.

Title: Sustained Attention
Definition: maintaining focus over time.

Title: Selective Attention
Definition: focusing on specific stimuli among others.

Title: Attentional Lapse
Definition: temporary failure of attention.

Title: Memory Process
Definition: an operation involved in encoding, storing, or retrieving information

Title: Episodic Memory Process
Definition: processing personal events with context.

Title: Semantic Memory Process
Definition: processing general world knowledge.

Title: Procedural Memory Process
Definition: processing skills and habits.

Title: Autobiographical Memory Process
Definition: processing personal past events.

Title: Thinking Process
Definition: manipulating information to reason, solve problems.

Title: Reasoning Process
Definition: drawing conclusions from information.

Title: Learning Process
Definition: acquiring new knowledge or skills.

Title: Metacognitive Process
Definition: thinking about one's own thinking.

Title: Time-Perception Process
Definition: subjective experience of duration.

Title: Interval-Timing Process
Definition: judging duration of intervals.

Title: Volitional Process
Definition: a mental operation related to will, motivation, and goal-directed action

Title: Motivational Process
Definition: driving behavior towards goals.

Title: Intention Formation Process
Definition: developing plans to act.

Title: Decision-Making Process
Definition: choosing among options.

Title: Self-Control Process
Definition: regulating impulses and behavior.

Title: Executive Function Process
Definition: higher-level cognitive control processes.

Title: Communicative Process
Definition: a mental operation involved in the exchange of information or meaning

Title: Language Production Process
Definition: generating spoken or written language.

Title: Language Comprehension Process
Definition: understanding spoken or written language.

Title: Inner Speech Process
Definition: internal verbal thinking.

Title: Nonverbal Communication Process
Definition: communicating without words.

Title: Social Communicative Interaction Process
Definition: exchanging meaning in social contexts.

Title: Developmental Process
Definition: a mental operation reflecting change over time in mental capacities or functioning

Title: Cognitive Development Process
Definition: changes in thinking over lifespan.

Title: Expertise Acquisition Process
Definition: developing high proficiency in skill.

Title: Cognitive Aging Process
Definition: changes in cognition with age.

Title: Creative Process
Definition: a mental operation involved in generating novel and valuable ideas or products

Title: Divergent Thinking Process
Definition: generating multiple possible solutions.

Title: Convergent Thinking Process
Definition: finding single best solution.

Title: Problem-Solving Process
Definition: finding solutions to obstacles.

Title: Emotional Regulation Process
Definition: a mental operation to influence the experience or expression of emotion

Title: Mental Content
Definition: information, beliefs, or representations held within the mind

Title: Mental Representation
Definition: a mental structure that stands for something else

Title: Mental Imagery
Definition: a sensory-like representation generated internally, often resembling the experience of actual perception.

Title: Sensory Modality-Specific Imagery
Definition: mental imagery primarily associated with a particular sensory system.

Title: Visual Imagery
Definition: mental imagery based on sight, including objects, scenes, and spatial layouts.

Title: Eidetic Imagery
Definition: unusually vivid, detailed, and persistent visual recall, akin to "photographic memory."

Title: Fantastical Visual Imagery
Definition: visual imagery of non-existent or impossible scenes (e.g., hallucinations, dreams).

Title: Auditory Imagery
Definition: mental imagery based on sound, including voices, music, environmental sounds.

Title: Musical Imagery
Definition: internal experience of melodies, harmonies, and rhythms.

Title: Verbal Imagery
Definition: internal "hearing" of words or speech.

Title: Olfactory Imagery
Definition: mental imagery based on smell (e.g., recalling the scent of coffee).

Title: Gustatory Imagery
Definition: mental imagery based on taste (e.g., recalling the taste of lemon).

Title: Somatosensory Imagery
Definition: mental imagery based on bodily sensations.

Title: Tactile Imagery
Definition: mental imagery of touch sensations (e.g., texture, pressure).

Title: Kinesthetic Imagery
Definition: mental imagery of bodily movement or position (e.g., imagining walking).

Title: Thermal Imagery
Definition: mental imagery of temperature sensations (e.g., imagining warmth or cold).

Title: Pain Imagery
Definition: mental imagery of pain sensations.

Title: Mental Model
Definition: an internal, dynamic representation of a system, situation, or phenomenon that allows for understanding, prediction, and explanation.

Title: Domain-Specific Mental Model
Definition: a mental model tailored to a particular area of knowledge or activity.

Title: System Mental Model
Definition: a mental model of how a particular physical or abstract system operates (e.g., a car engine, computer software).

Title: Functional Mental Model
Definition: represents the purpose and intended behavior of system components.

Title: Structural Mental Model
Definition: represents the physical or logical arrangement of system components.

Title: Process Mental Model
Definition: represents the sequence of operations or transformations within a system.

Title: Task Mental Model
Definition: a mental model of how to perform a specific task, including goals, steps, and required resources.

Title: Social Mental Model
Definition: a mental model of social interactions, group dynamics, or societal structures.

Title: Other Minds Model (Theory of Mind)
Definition: model of the beliefs, intentions, and desires of other individuals.

Title: Group Dynamics Model
Definition: model of how groups behave and interact.

Title: Situational Model
Definition: a dynamic mental model representing the current state and likely future states of an immediate environment or context.

Title: Current State Model
Definition: represents what is happening now in the situation.

Title: Environmental State Model
Definition: model of the physical surroundings and their properties (e.g., weather, terrain).

Title: System State Model (Situational Context)
Definition: model of the current configuration and operational status of relevant systems within the situation.

Title: Agent State Model (Situational Context)
Definition: model of the current internal states (e.g., location, actions, immediate goals) of other agents involved in the situation.

Title: Future State Model
Definition: represents predictions or projections of how the situation will evolve.

Title: Trend Extrapolation Model
Definition: projection based on observed patterns or trajectories (e.g., speed and direction of a moving object).

Title: Event Prediction Model
Definition: anticipation of specific future events or outcomes (e.g., a collision, a change in system status).

Title: Consequence Projection Model
Definition: mental simulation of the potential results of one's own actions or external events on the situation.

Title: Explanatory Model
Definition: represents the underlying reasons, causes, or constraints for the current situation.

Title: Causal Attribution Model
Definition: understanding why events or behaviors occurred within the situation.

Title: Anomaly Explanation Model
Definition: providing a reason or rationale for unexpected or unusual observations in the situation.

Title: Conceptual Category
Definition: a mental grouping of distinct entities (objects, events, ideas) based on shared properties, relationships, or functions.

Title: Formation Basis of Category
Definition: how a conceptual category is acquired or structured.

Title: Natural Kind Concept
Definition: a conceptual category referring to naturally occurring groupings whose members share intrinsic properties (e.g., "bird," "water," "tree").

Title: Artifact Concept
Definition: a conceptual category referring to human-made objects, often defined by their intended function or design (e.g., "chair," "hammer").

Title: Ad Hoc Category
Definition: a conceptual category formed temporarily for a specific purpose or context, often lacking stable defining features (e.g., "things to take on a picnic," "things that could fall on your head").

Title: Goal-Derived Category
Definition: a conceptual category whose members serve a common goal or satisfy a particular function, regardless of their superficial similarity (e.g., "things to lose weight," "things to escape a fire").

Title: Structure of Category
Definition: the internal organization or representation of a conceptual category.

Title: Prototype Theory of Concepts
Definition: categories are structured around a central, idealized member (the prototype) that best exemplifies the category's features, with graded membership.

Title: Exemplar Theory of Concepts
Definition: categories are represented by a collection of individual stored examples (exemplars) of category members, with new items compared to these stored examples.

Title: Theory-Theory of Concepts
Definition: categories are structured by miniature, implicit theories or explanatory frameworks that guide understanding and classification.

Title: Classical View of Concepts
Definition: categories are defined by a set of necessary and sufficient conditions that all members must possess (less commonly held in modern cognitive science).

Title: Belief
Definition: a mental representation of a proposition or state of affairs accepted by an individual as true or factual.

Title: Epistemic Status of Belief
Definition: classification based on the justification or source of knowledge.

Title: Justified Belief
Definition: a belief held with adequate evidence, reasoning, or support.

Title: Empirically Justified Belief
Definition: based on sensory experience or observation.

Title: Logically Justified Belief
Definition: based on principles of reason or formal deduction.

Title: Testimonially Justified Belief
Definition: based on reliable testimony from others.

Title: Unjustified Belief
Definition: a belief held without adequate evidence or reason.

Title: False Belief
Definition: a belief that does not correspond to reality.

Title: True Belief
Definition: a belief that corresponds to reality.

Title: Form of Belief
Definition: how the belief is held or expressed mentally.

Title: Propositional Belief
Definition: a belief that can be expressed as a declarative statement or proposition (e.g., "It is raining").

Title: Dispositional Belief
Definition: a tendency to act or feel as if a proposition is true, even if not consciously affirmed or considered at every moment.

Title: Occurrent Belief
Definition: a belief that is actively present in conscious thought at a given moment.

Title: Content Domain of Belief
Definition: the subject matter of the belief.

Title: Factual Belief
Definition: belief concerning objective states of affairs (e.g., "Water boils at 100°C").

Title: Value Belief
Definition: belief concerning what is good, bad, right, or wrong (e.g., "Honesty is important").

Title: Self-Belief
Definition: belief about one's own characteristics, abilities, or identity.

Title: Social Belief
Definition: belief about social groups, norms, or societal structures.

Title: Centrality of Belief
Definition: the importance or interconnectedness of a belief within an individual's belief system.

Title: Core Belief
Definition: fundamental, often unconscious, and highly resistant to change; forms the foundation of one's worldview.

Title: Peripheral Belief
Definition: less central, more easily changed beliefs that are often derived from or supported by core beliefs.

Title: Desire
Definition: a mental representation of a desired outcome, state, or object, accompanied by a motivational pull towards its realization.

Title: Origin/Nature of Desire
Definition: classification based on the source or fundamental drive.

Title: Basic Desire (Primary/Biological)
Definition: fundamental, often instinctual desires related to survival and well-being (e.g., for food, water, sleep, safety, procreation).

Title: Acquired Desire (Secondary/Learned)
Definition: desires that are learned or developed through experience, culture, or social interaction (e.g., for money, fame, knowledge).

Title: Functional Role of Desire
Definition: how the desire relates to other goals or outcomes.

Title: Instrumental Desire
Definition: a desire for something as a means to achieve another, more ultimate desire or goal.

Title: Terminal Desire (Intrinsic)
Definition: a desire for something as an end in itself, valued for its own sake.

Title: Awareness of Desire
Definition: the level of conscious access to the desire.

Title: Conscious Desire
Definition: a desire that one is explicitly aware of and can articulate.

Title: Unconscious Desire
Definition: a desire that operates outside of conscious awareness but influences behavior and thought.

Title: Semantic Network
Definition: a mental representation where concepts are nodes and the relationships between them are links, forming a structured knowledge representation.

Title: Structural Type of Semantic Network
Definition: how the network is organized.

Title: Hierarchical Semantic Network
Definition: concepts are organized in a hierarchy, typically using "is-a" (subsumption) and "has-a" (part-whole) links, allowing for property inheritance.

Title: Propositional Semantic Network
Definition: represents knowledge as propositions (statements that can be true or false) where concepts are nodes and relationships form propositions.

Title: Processing Model of Semantic Network
Definition: how information is accessed and processed within the network.

Title: Spreading Activation Model
Definition: activation spreads from an activated node to related nodes, with strength decreasing with distance, explaining priming effects.

Title: Self Representation
Definition: a mental structure representing aspects of one's own personhood

Title: Self-Concept
Definition: overall beliefs about oneself.

Title: Personal Identity
Definition: sense of continuity and uniqueness of self.

Title: Social Identity
Definition: part of self-concept from group membership.

Title: Memory Content
Definition: stored information accessible through memory processes

Title: Episodic Memory Content
Definition: memories of specific events.

Title: Semantic Memory Content
Definition: general knowledge, facts.

Title: Procedural Memory Content
Definition: memories of how to do things.

Title: Autobiographical Memory Content
Definition: memories about one's life.

Title: Mental Attribute
Definition: an inherent quality, property, or characteristic of the mind or mental entities

Title: Arousal Dimension
Definition: a dimension of intensity or energy in mental states

Title: Physiological Arousal
Definition: the physical manifestation of mental arousal, involving bodily systems.

Title: Autonomic Arousal
Definition: arousal mediated by the autonomic nervous system.

Title: Sympathetic Arousal
Definition: 'fight or flight' response, increasing heart rate, blood pressure.

Title: Parasympathetic Arousal
Definition: 'rest and digest' response, decreasing heart rate, promoting relaxation.

Title: Cortical Arousal
Definition: arousal related to brain activity and alertness, measured by EEG.

Title: Alpha Wave Dominance
Definition: characteristic of a relaxed, yet alert state.

Title: Beta Wave Dominance
Definition: characteristic of an alert, active, and focused state.

Title: Delta/Theta Wave Dominance
Definition: characteristic of deep sleep or highly relaxed/meditative states.

Title: Subjective Arousal
Definition: the conscious experience of mental intensity or energy.

Title: High Subjective Arousal
Definition: feelings of being energized, alert, excited, or stressed.

Title: Low Subjective Arousal
Definition: feelings of being calm, relaxed, sluggish, or bored.

Title: Valence Dimension
Definition: a dimension of pleasantness or unpleasantness in mental states

Title: Positive Valence
Definition: the inherent quality of being pleasant, desirable, or rewarding.

Title: Hedonic Pleasure
Definition: direct sensory or emotional pleasure (e.g., taste, warmth, joy).

Title: Eudaimonic Well-being Component
Definition: component of well-being derived from meaning, purpose, and self-realization.

Title: Negative Valence
Definition: the inherent quality of being unpleasant, undesirable, or aversive.

Title: Aversive Discomfort
Definition: direct sensory or emotional pain/discomfort (e.g., physical pain, sadness, fear).

Title: Threat-Related Aversion
Definition: unpleasantness arising from perceived danger or harm.

Title: Neutral Valence
Definition: the absence of significant pleasantness or unpleasantness.

Title: Mental Capacity
Definition: an inherent ability or potential for mental functioning (e.g., capacity for attention, memory capacity) - Potential for performing mental operations.

Title: Cognitive Capacity
Definition: an inherent ability or potential for specific cognitive processes.

Title: Attentional Capacity
Definition: the maximum amount of information or stimuli that can be processed simultaneously or maintained in focus.

Title: Sustained Attentional Capacity
Definition: potential to maintain focus over prolonged periods.

Title: Divided Attentional Capacity
Definition: potential to attend to multiple stimuli or tasks concurrently.

Title: Memory Capacity
Definition: the inherent potential of the memory system to encode, store, and retrieve information.

Title: Working Memory Capacity
Definition: the limited capacity for holding and manipulating information temporarily.

Title: Long-Term Memory Capacity
Definition: the vast, theoretically unlimited capacity for durable storage of information.

Title: Processing Speed Capacity
Definition: the inherent potential for how quickly mental operations can be performed.

Title: Reasoning Capacity
Definition: the inherent potential to draw logical inferences and solve complex problems.

Title: Deductive Reasoning Capacity
Definition: potential to derive specific conclusions from general premises.

Title: Inductive Reasoning Capacity
Definition: potential to derive general principles from specific observations.

Title: Problem-Solving Capacity
Definition: the inherent potential to find solutions to novel or complex situations.

Title: Affective Capacity
Definition: an inherent ability or potential related to emotional experience and regulation.

Title: Emotional Experience Capacity
Definition: the potential range and depth of emotions an individual can experience.

Title: Emotional Regulation Capacity
Definition: the potential to manage and adjust one's emotional responses.

Title: Volitional Capacity
Definition: an inherent ability or potential related to will, motivation, and goal-directed action.

Title: Self-Control Capacity
Definition: the potential to resist impulses and pursue long-term goals.

Title: Motivational Capacity
Definition: the inherent potential to generate and sustain goal-directed energy.

Title: Mental Structure/Subsystem
Definition: a hypothesized enduring division or component of the mind, often with distinct functions or properties.

Title: Levels of Consciousness (Topographical Model)
Definition: hypothesized layers of mental accessibility.

Title: Conscious Mind
Definition: the part of the mind that holds current awareness and direct experience.

Title: Active Awareness
Definition: that which is currently in focal attention.

Title: Peripheral Awareness
Definition: that which is currently registered but not in focal attention.

Title: Preconscious Mind
Definition: the part of the mind containing information that is not currently in awareness but can be readily retrieved.

Title: Accessible Memories
Definition: non-repressed memories that can be brought to conscious awareness.

Title: Latent Knowledge
Definition: knowledge not currently used but retrievable for problem-solving or response.

Title: Unconscious Mind (Topographical)
Definition: the part of the mind containing thoughts, memories, and desires of which one is not aware but which can influence behavior.

Title: Repressed Content
Definition: thoughts or memories actively kept out of conscious awareness due to psychological defense mechanisms.

Title: Automatic Processes
Definition: cognitive or behavioral operations that occur without conscious awareness or effort.

Title: Structural Components of Psyche (Freudian Model)
Definition: hypothesized functional divisions of the personality.

Title: Id
Definition: the primitive, instinctual, and pleasure-seeking component of the personality, operating entirely unconsciously, driven by the pleasure principle.

Title: Libido (Id Component)
Definition: the psychic energy or drive associated with life instincts, including sexual and pleasure-seeking urges.

Title: Thanatos (Id Component)
Definition: the psychic energy or drive associated with death instincts, including aggression and destructive urges.

Title: Ego
Definition: the largely conscious, rational component of the personality that mediates between the demands of the id, the superego, and reality, operating by the reality principle.

Title: Executive Function (Ego Role)
Definition: the planning, decision-making, and self-regulation capacities of the ego.

Title: Defense Mechanism (Ego Role)
Definition: unconscious strategies used by the ego to protect itself from anxiety or unpleasant thoughts.

Title: Superego
Definition: the internalized moral component of the personality, representing ideals and societal standards, often operating unconsciously.

Title: Conscience (Superego Component)
Definition: the part of the superego that punishes behavior that violates moral standards, leading to guilt.

Title: Ego Ideal (Superego Component)
Definition: the part of the superego that represents ideal standards of behavior, leading to feelings of pride when achieved.

Title: Archetypes (Jungian Model)
Definition: universal, archaic patterns and images that derive from the collective unconscious and are the psychic counterpart of instinct.

Title: Persona (Archetype)
Definition: the social mask or role an individual presents to the world, often for public acceptance.

Title: Social Role Persona
Definition: the specific mask adopted for a particular social context (e.g., professional, student).

Title: Ideal Self Persona
Definition: the persona striving to meet societal expectations of perfection.

Title: Shadow (Archetype)
Definition: the unconscious aspect of the personality that the conscious ego does not identify with, often containing undesirable or repressed qualities.

Title: Personal Shadow
Definition: repressed aspects stemming from individual experience.

Title: Collective Shadow
Definition: universally denied or repressed aspects of humanity.

Title: Anima/Animus (Archetype)
Definition: the unconscious feminine image in a man (Anima) / masculine image in a woman (Animus), representing the contrasexual soul image.

Title: Anima (Male Psyche)
Definition: the feminine principle in men.

Title: Animus (Female Psyche)
Definition: the masculine principle in women.

Title: Self (Jungian Archetype)
Definition: the central archetype, representing the unification and totality of consciousness and unconsciousness, aiming for individuation.

Title: Mandalas (Self Symbol)
Definition: circular images often symbolizing the unified Self.

Title: Wholeness (Self Characteristic)
Definition: the ultimate aim of individuation, representing the integration of all psychic aspects.

Title: Great Mother (Archetype)
Definition: archetype symbolizing nurturing, fertility, and destructive aspects of the feminine principle.

Title: Wise Old Man (Archetype)
Definition: archetype symbolizing wisdom, guidance, and spiritual authority.

Title: Hero (Archetype)
Definition: archetype symbolizing courage, struggle, and overcoming adversity.

Title: Core Self (Non-Psychodynamic Models)
Definition: concepts representing a fundamental, authentic, and enduring aspect of an individual's identity, distinct from transient thoughts or emotions.

Title: Narrative Self
Definition: the self as constructed and understood through personal stories, life experiences, and the ongoing integration of past, present, and future.

Title: Autobiographical Narrative Self
Definition: the personal story based on episodic memories of one's own life.

Title: Social Narrative Self
Definition: the self-story influenced by social interactions and cultural expectations.

Title: Experiential Self (Minimal Self)
Definition: the self as directly experienced in the present moment, encompassing immediate consciousness and agency, often considered pre-reflective.

Title: Embodied Self
Definition: the sense of self rooted in one's physical body and its sensations.

Title: Subjective Point of View
Definition: the self as the unique perspective from which experiences are perceived.

Title: True Self (Humanistic)
Definition: the authentic, inherent self, often believed to be discovered through self-actualization, distinct from societal or imposed identities.

Title: Actualizing Tendency (Component)
Definition: the innate drive toward growth and fulfillment of one's potential.

Title: Organismic Valuing Process (Component)
Definition: the innate capacity to evaluate experiences in terms of whether they promote or hinder actualization.

Title: Cognitive Architecture
Definition: a comprehensive theory or model of the structure and function of the human mind, often expressed computationally, specifying how various cognitive processes interact.

Title: General Problem Solver (GPS) Architecture
Definition: an early AI cognitive architecture aiming to simulate human problem-solving through means-ends analysis.

Title: Production Rule System (GPS Component)
Definition: "if-then" rules representing knowledge and actions.

Title: Working Memory (GPS Component)
Definition: temporary storage for current problem state.

Title: ACT-R Architecture (Adaptive Control of Thought—Rational)
Definition: a cognitive architecture that models human cognition by integrating symbolic and sub-symbolic processing, based on modular components.

Title: Declarative Memory Module (ACT-R)
Definition: stores factual and episodic knowledge as "chunks."

Title: Procedural Memory Module (ACT-R)
Definition: stores knowledge about how to do things as production rules.

Title: Decision Cycle (SOAR)
Definition: the fundamental process by which SOAR operates, involving elaboration, proposal, deliberation, and application.

Title: Working Memory Buffers (ACT-R)
Definition: temporary holding places for information from other modules.

Title: SOAR Architecture (State Operator And Result)
Definition: a cognitive architecture based on universal subgoaling and chunking to model intelligent behavior.

Title: Long-Term Memory (SOAR)
Definition: includes procedural and declarative knowledge.

Title: Enduring Personality Structure (Trait Models)
Definition: stable, measurable predispositions that constitute the fundamental building blocks of an individual's personality, theorized as internal structures.

Title: Big Five Personality Factors (OCEAN)
Definition: a widely accepted model proposing five broad dimensions of personality.

Title: Openness to Experience (Factor)
Definition: characterized by imagination, intellectual curiosity, and aesthetic sensitivity.

Title: Conscientiousness (Factor)
Definition: characterized by organization, self-discipline, and responsibility.

Title: Extraversion (Factor)
Definition: characterized by sociability, assertiveness, and energetic behavior.

Title: Agreeableness (Factor)
Definition: characterized by compassion, cooperativeness, and trustworthiness.

Title: Neuroticism (Factor)
Definition: characterized by emotional instability, anxiety, and negative affect.

Title: Eysenck's PEN Model
Definition: a trait theory proposing three superfactors of personality.

Title: Psychoticism (Factor)
Definition: characterized by aggression, impulsivity, and non-conformity.

Title: Extraversion (Factor)
Definition: characterized by sociability and outgoingness.

Title: Neuroticism (Factor)
Definition: characterized by emotional instability and anxiety.

Title: Temperament Factors
Definition: innate, biologically based individual differences in behavioral style and emotional reactivity, appearing early in life.

Title: Activity Level (Temperament)
Definition: refers to a person's general level of motor activity.

Title: Emotionality (Temperament)
Definition: refers to the intensity of emotional reactions.

Title: Sociability (Temperament)
Definition: refers to a person's tendency to affiliate with others.

Title: Motivational Drive Systems
Definition: hypothesized internal structures or processes that generate and direct goal-oriented behavior, often rooted in biological or psychological needs.

Title: Behavioral Activation System (BAS)
Definition: a hypothesized system regulating motivation to approach rewards and engage in goal-directed behavior.

Title: Drive (BAS Component)
Definition: the impulse to pursue desired goals.

Title: Reward Responsiveness (BAS Component)
Definition: sensitivity to positive outcomes and incentives.

Title: Behavioral Inhibition System (BIS)
Definition: a hypothesized system regulating motivation to avoid punishments and inhibit behavior in the face of conflict or threat.

Title: Fear (BIS Component)
Definition: the response to conditioned aversive stimuli.

Title: Anxiety (BIS Component)
Definition: the response to potential threats or uncertainty.

Title: Homeostatic Regulation System
Definition: internal systems that maintain physiological equilibrium (e.g., hunger, thirst drives).

Title: Thirst Drive System
Definition: the internal mechanism prompting water intake.

Title: Hunger Drive System
Definition: the internal mechanism prompting food intake.

Title: Memory Systems (Structural)
Definition: distinct, functionally specialized components of the memory apparatus within the mind.

Title: Sensory Memory System
Definition: very brief storage for incoming sensory information.

Title: Iconic Memory
Definition: visual sensory memory.

Title: Echoic Memory
Definition: auditory sensory memory.

Title: Working Memory System
Definition: a limited-capacity system for temporarily holding and manipulating information during complex cognitive tasks.

Title: Phonological Loop
Definition: a component for processing and temporarily storing auditory and verbal information.

Title: Visuospatial Sketchpad
Definition: a component for processing and temporarily storing visual and spatial information.

Title: Central Executive
Definition: an attentional control system that supervises and coordinates the activity of the phonological loop and visuospatial sketchpad.

Title: Long-Term Memory System
Definition: a vast, relatively permanent storage system for information.

Title: Declarative Memory System (Explicit Memory)
Definition: memory for facts and events that can be consciously recalled.

Title: Episodic Memory System
Definition: memory for specific personal experiences and events with contextual details.

Title: Semantic Memory System
Definition: memory for general world knowledge, facts, concepts, and language meaning.

Title: Non-Declarative Memory System (Implicit Memory)
Definition: memory for skills, habits, and other forms of learning that are not consciously recalled.

Title: Procedural Memory System
Definition: memory for motor skills and habits (e.g., riding a bike).

Title: Priming System
Definition: the unconscious influence of previous exposure to a stimulus on subsequent responses.

Title: Mental Mechanism
Definition: an underlying functional system or structure hypothesized to subserve mental processes

Title: Behavioral Activation System
Definition: a hypothesized system regulating motivation to approach rewards

Title: Behavioral Avoidance System
Definition: a hypothesized system regulating motivation to avoid punishments

Title: Mental Phenomenon
Definition: a discrete event, occurrence, or subjective experience in the mind that is not primarily defined as a state or ongoing process

Title: Insight Experience
Definition: a sudden realization or understanding

Title: Mental Condition
Definition: a pattern of mental functioning considered atypical, impaired, or pathological

Title: Mental Disorder
Definition: a clinically recognized pattern of symptoms affecting mental functioning

Title: Anxiety Disorder
Definition: characterized by excessive worry or fear.

Title: Major Depressive Disorder
Definition: characterized by persistent sadness or loss of interest.

Title: Bipolar Disorder
Definition: characterized by mood swings between depression and mania.

Title: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
Definition: develops after experiencing a traumatic event.

Title: Social
Definition: The domain encompassing collective entities, structures, processes, and forms arising from the interaction of conscious agents

Title: Social Entity
Definition: A unit or agentive grouping within the social domain, characterized by a degree of internal coherence, boundary, and capacity for collective reference or action.

Title: Dyad
Definition: A social entity consisting of exactly two interacting individuals.

Title: Romantic Dyad
Definition: A dyad based on a romantic or marital relationship.

Title: Friendship Dyad
Definition: A dyad based on a bond of mutual affection and companionship.

Title: Professional Dyad
Definition: A dyad formed for work-related purposes or within a professional context.

Title: Mentor-Mentee Dyad
Definition: A professional dyad where one individual guides another.

Title: Collaborative Pair (Professional)
Definition: A professional dyad working jointly on a task.

Title: Kinship Dyad
Definition: A dyad based on family ties (blood, marriage, or adoption).

Title: Spousal Dyad
Definition: (overlaps with Romantic Dyad, but emphasizes legal/kinship aspect)

Title: Adversarial Dyad
Definition: A dyad characterized by conflict or direct opposition between the two individuals.

Title: Small Group
Definition: A social entity composed of a limited number of individuals (typically 3 to about 20) who interact regularly, share common goals or identity, and perceive themselves as a group.

Title: Family Unit
Definition: A small group based on kinship ties, often cohabiting and sharing emotional and material resources.

Title: Nuclear Family Unit
Definition: A family unit typically comprising two parents and their dependent children.

Title: Extended Family Unit (Cohabiting)
Definition: A family unit that includes relatives beyond the nuclear family living together or in close proximity and functioning as a single household unit.

Title: Peer Group
Definition: A small group of individuals sharing similar age, social status, background, or interests.

Title: Professional Peer Group
Definition: (e.g., a small group of colleagues at the same level)

Title: Task Group / Work Team
Definition: A small group formed specifically to accomplish a defined task or project.

Title: Jury
Definition: (as a small task group)

Title: Support Group
Definition: A small group whose members provide mutual aid, emotional comfort, and resources for shared challenges or experiences.

Title: Clique
Definition: A small, often exclusive, group of individuals who interact frequently and share strong common interests, sometimes exhibiting strong in-group loyalty.

Title: Focus Group (Research)
Definition: A small group of individuals assembled to participate in a guided discussion for qualitative research purposes.

Title: Social Club (Small Scale)
Definition: A small group organized around shared leisure activities or social interests.

Title: Community
Definition: A social entity comprising a group of people with a shared identity, interests, values, or geographic location, who interact and often share a sense of belonging or mutual interdependence.

Title: Geographic Community
Definition: A community defined by shared physical locality and the social interactions within it.

Title: Neighborhood Community
Definition: A community within a specific residential area of a town or city.

Title: Village Community
Definition: A small, often rural, geographic community.

Title: Town Community
Definition: A geographic community larger than a village but smaller than a city.

Title: Community of Interest
Definition: A community formed around a shared passion, hobby, concern, or intellectual pursuit, not necessarily tied to geography.

Title: Hobbyist Community
Definition: (e.g., gaming community, gardening club members)

Title: Activist Community
Definition: (e.g., a group of environmental activists sharing a common goal)

Title: Fan Community / Fandom
Definition: A community built around shared enthusiasm for a particular cultural phenomenon (e.g., a musician, TV series, book).

Title: Community of Practice
Definition: A community of people who share a concern or a passion for something they do and learn how to do it better as they interact regularly.

Title: Online Community / Virtual Community
Definition: A community whose members primarily interact via digital communication media, often transcending geographical boundaries.

Title: Intentional Community
Definition: A planned residential community whose members share explicit common social, economic, or ecological values and goals. (e.g., cohousing, ecovillage, commune)

Title: Ethnic Community
Definition: A community based on shared ethnicity, cultural heritage, traditions, and often language.

Title: Religious Congregation / Faith Community
Definition: A community of individuals sharing common religious beliefs and practices, often gathering for worship and mutual support.

Title: Professional Community (Broad)
Definition: A community of individuals in the same profession or field, sharing knowledge, standards, and experience (can be broader than a single Community of Practice).

Title: Diaspora Community
Definition: A community of people from a common homeland who are dispersed or scattered in other places, maintaining a sense of connection to their origin.

Title: Formal Organization
Definition: A social entity deliberately constructed and structured to achieve specific goals, characterized by explicit rules, roles, and a hierarchy of authority.

Title: Governmental Organization
Definition: An organization that is part of the structure of a state or public administration.

Title: Legislative Body
Definition: (e.g., Parliament, Congress, City Council)

Title: Executive Agency / Department
Definition: (e.g., Ministry of Health, Environmental Protection Agency)

Title: Judicial Body / Court System
Definition: (as an organizational entity, e.g., Supreme Court, District Court)

Title: Intergovernmental Organization (IGO)
Definition: An organization composed primarily of sovereign states. (e.g., United Nations, World Trade Organization, European Union)

Title: Regulatory Agency
Definition: A governmental organization responsible for setting and enforcing standards and regulations.

Title: Public Service Broadcaster
Definition: A state-funded or publicly owned media organization.

Title: Professional Association / Body
Definition: A formal organization of professionals in a specific field, often for mutual benefit, development, and self-regulation.

Title: Labor Union / Trade Union
Definition: A formal organization of workers formed to protect and advance their collective interests regarding wages, benefits, and working conditions.

Title: Financial Institution
Definition: A formal organization dealing with financial and monetary transactions. (e.g., Bank, Insurance Company, Investment Firm, Stock Exchange).

Title: Media Organization
Definition: A formal organization involved in producing and distributing news, entertainment, or other information to a mass audience. (e.g., Newspaper Publisher, Broadcasting Network, Film Studio, Publishing House).

Title: Research Organization (Independent)
Definition: A formal organization primarily dedicated to conducting research, not necessarily affiliated with a university.

Title: Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) / Non-Profit Organization (NPO)
Definition: An organization that operates independently of government, typically for social, charitable, or advocacy purposes, not primarily for profit.

Title: Charitable Organization
Definition: (focused on philanthropy and social well-being)

Title: Advocacy Organization
Definition: (focused on influencing public policy or opinion)

Title: Service Delivery Organization
Definition: (Non-Profit) (focused on providing specific services like healthcare or education)

Title: Foundation (Grant-Making)
Definition: A non-profit organization that supports other organizations or individuals through grants.

Title: Think Tank
Definition: An organization that conducts research and advocacy on policy issues.

Title: Business Enterprise / For-Profit Organization
Definition: An organization primarily aiming to generate profit for its owners.

Title: Partnership
Definition: (Business)

Title: Multinational Corporation
Definition: (MNC)

Title: Small and Medium-sized Enterprise
Definition: (SME) (as a corporate form)

Title: Cooperative (Business)
Definition: A business owned and operated by and for its members.

Title: State-Owned Enterprise (SOE) (Commercial)
Definition: A business enterprise owned by the state but operating on a commercial basis.

Title: Social Enterprise (For-Profit Structure)
Definition: A for-profit business with explicit social objectives as a core part of its mission.

Title: Educational Institution
Definition: A formal organization dedicated to education and learning.

Title: Research Institute
Definition: (Affiliated with Educational Institution)

Title: Healthcare Organization
Definition: A formal organization providing medical or health-related services.

Title: Religious Organization (Institutional)
Definition: A formal, structured organization dedicated to religious worship, administration, propagation, or service. (e.g., a specific church denomination, a diocese, a religious order, a missionary society).

Title: Political Organization
Definition: A formal organization involved in political processes or governance.

Title: Military Organization
Definition: A formal organization authorized by a state (or other recognized authority) to use force, particularly lethal force, in defense or pursuit of its interests.

Title: Cultural Organization
Definition: A formal organization focused on creating, preserving, exhibiting, or promoting cultural works or heritage.

Title: Library
Definition: (as an organization)

Title: Performing Arts Company
Definition: (e.g., orchestra, theater company, dance troupe)

Title: Archive
Definition: (as an organization)

Title: Social Network Entity (Relational Structure)
Definition: A social entity defined by a specific set of conscious agents (nodes) and the pattern of their interrelationships (ties), considered as a bounded collective unit.

Title: Personal Network Entity
Definition: The set of direct and indirect social connections surrounding a focal individual, considered as a collective unit.

Title: Organizational Communication Network Entity
Definition: The pattern of communication relationships among members within a formal organization, viewed as a distinct entity.

Title: Inter-Organizational Network Entity
Definition: The pattern of relationships connecting multiple formal organizations, considered as a collective unit. (e.g., a strategic alliance network, a supply chain network).

Title: Online Social Platform User Network Entity
Definition: The entire collection of users and their declared connections on a specific online social platform, considered as a single, bounded social entity (distinct from the platform technology itself).

Title: Co-authorship Network Entity
Definition: The collection of researchers (agents) and their co-authorship links (relationships), representing a collaborative intellectual structure.

Title: Elite Network Entity
Definition: A network entity composed of individuals holding prominent positions of power or influence within or across societal sectors.

Title: Crowd
Definition: A temporary, relatively unstructured gathering of a large number of individuals in close physical proximity, often sharing a common focus of attention but typically lacking the cohesion of more organized groups.

Title: Casual Crowd
Definition: A crowd that comes together spontaneously with loose organization and little sustained interaction (e.g., people on a busy street, shoppers in a mall at a given moment).

Title: Conventional Crowd
Definition: A crowd that gathers for a scheduled event and shares a common focus, with behavior governed by established norms (e.g., audience at a concert, attendees at a sporting event).

Title: Expressive Crowd
Definition: A crowd that forms to express an emotion or release tension, often at events like rallies, concerts, or celebrations (e.g., a New Year's Eve crowd, a sports crowd celebrating).

Title: Acting Crowd
Definition: A crowd that engages in overt, often collective, action, which can be volatile and emotionally charged (e.g., a mob, a riot, a panic-stricken crowd fleeing danger).

Title: Protest Crowd / Demonstration Group
Definition: A crowd gathered to publicly express objection or support for a cause, policy, or event.

Title: Population Segment / Demographic Group
Definition: A social entity consisting of a collection of individuals within a larger population, defined by shared demographic, social, or statistical characteristics, and often treated as a distinct unit for social analysis, policy, or address.

Title: Age Cohort
Definition: (e.g., Generation Z, Baby Boomers, Senior Citizens as a demographic group).

Title: Gender-Defined Group
Definition: (as a social category, e.g., women as a demographic in workforce studies).

Title: Socioeconomic Class Segment
Definition: (e.g., the population segment identified as 'upper-middle class' in a survey).

Title: Electorate / Voter Segment
Definition: (e.g., registered voters in a district, a segment of undecided voters).

Title: Consumer Segment / Market Segment
Definition: (e.g., early adopters of technology, luxury goods consumers).

Title: Audience Segment
Definition: (e.g., prime-time television viewers, readers of a specific genre).

Title: Ethnic or Racial Demographic Group
Definition: (as defined for statistical or social analysis purposes).

Title: Society
Definition: A large-scale, enduring, and relatively self-sufficient social entity comprising individuals and groups interconnected through a complex web of relationships, sharing a common culture, and typically occupying a defined territory and organized under a common political and economic system.

Title: Nation-State Society
Definition: a society coterminous with the territory and government of a sovereign state.

Title: City-State Society
Definition: a Nation-State Society organized around a single dominant urban centre and its immediate hinterland.

Title: Caral
Definition: the principal urban polity of the Norte Chico civilization in coastal Peru, noted for its monumental plazas and centralized authority (c. 3500–3000 BCE).

Title: Tyre
Definition: a Phoenician maritime trade society on the Levantine coast, famed for purple dye, shipbuilding, and colonization (c. 1200–538 BCE).

Title: Sidon
Definition: the Phoenician city-state in the Levant, noted for purple dye and maritime commerce (c. 3000–550 BCE).

Title: Byblos
Definition: the ancient Levantine city-state, early adopter of alphabetic script and trade (c. 5000–332 BCE).

Title: Arwad
Definition: the island city-state off Syria, important Phoenician naval station (c. 1300 BCE–64 BCE).

Title: Utica
Definition: the Phoenician colony on North Africa’s coast, early rival to Carthage (c. 1101–146 BCE).

Title: Gadir (Gades)
Definition: the Phoenician colony on the Iberian Atlantic coast, one of the oldest Western Mediterranean settlements (c. 1100–206 BCE).

Title: Veii
Definition: an Etruscan city-state north of Rome, rival of early Roman monarchy and Republic (c. 8th–4th centuries BCE; destroyed 396 BCE).

Title: Tarquinia
Definition: a major Etruscan city-state on the Tyrrhenian coast, noted for its painted tombs and maritime trade (c. 8th–3rd centuries BCE).

Title: Caere (Cerveteri)
Definition: an Etruscan city-state in southern Etruria, famed for its tumulus necropolises and trade networks (c. 9th–3rd centuries BCE).

Title: Vulci
Definition: an Etruscan city-state in southern Etruria, noted for its wealth, art, and iron-smelting (c. 8th–3rd centuries BCE).

Title: Volsinii (Orvieto)
Definition: an Etruscan city-state in central Italy, renowned for its bronze industry; destroyed by Rome in 264 BCE (c. 7th–3rd centuries BCE).

Title: Populonia
Definition: the principal Etruscan port and centre of iron smelting on the Tyrrhenian coast (c. 8th–3rd centuries BCE).

Title: Felsina (Bologna)
Definition: an Etruscan city-state in northern Italy, precursor to the Roman colony Bononia (c. 6th–3rd centuries BCE).

Title: Harappa
Definition: a major urban polity of the Indus Valley Civilization, characterized by grid-plan cities, standardized weights, and a centralized administration (c. 2600–1900 BCE).

Title: Mohenjo-daro
Definition: the principal city-state of the Mature Harappan phase, renowned for its advanced civic planning, drainage systems, and state authority (c. 2500–1900 BCE).

Title: Eridu
Definition: the earliest known city-state in southern Mesopotamia with centralized temple authority (c. 4000 BCE).

Title: Uruk
Definition: the first large-scale urban state in Sumer, noted for its administrative bureaucracy and monumental construction (c. 4000–3100 BCE).

Title: Ur
Definition: a major Sumerian city-state on the Persian Gulf coast, centered on a ziggurat and a temple economy (c. 2600–1800 BCE).

Title: Kish
Definition: an early northern Mesopotamian city-state famed for its dynastic kingship and political preeminence in Sumer (c. 3500 BCE).

Title: Lagash
Definition: a Sumerian city-state that achieved significant political autonomy and artistic patronage in the late 4th millennium BCE.

Title: Susa
Definition: an early Elamite city-state in southwestern Iran, characterized by centralized governance and temple complexes (c. 4000–3000 BCE).

Title: Knossos
Definition: the Minoan palace-city on Crete, early Bronze Age centre of administration and ritual (c. 1900–1400 BCE).

Title: Maya City-State Society
Definition: Classic Maya polities (c. 400 BCE–900 CE).

Title: Tikal
Definition: the great Petén Basin polity with towering temples, stelae, and a powerful dynasty (c. 200–900 CE)

Title: Cobá
Definition: northern lowlands site with raised roads (sacbé), large pyramid Nohoch Mul (c. 100–900 CE)

Title: Calakmul
Definition: the “Snake Kingdom,” rival of Tikal, famed for its twin pyramids and far-flung alliances (c. 500–850 CE)

Title: Palenque
Definition: the Chiapas city-state celebrated for its intricate stucco-decorated palaces and the reign of Kʼinich Janaabʼ Pakal (c. 226 BCE–799 CE)

Title: Copán
Definition: the Honduran polity known for its Hieroglyphic Stairway, sculpted altars, and royal tombs (c. 400–800 CE)

Title: Caracol
Definition: major Belize site with dynastic stelae and sprawling causeways (c. 550–859 CE)

Title: Yaxchilán
Definition: Usumacinta-river polity renowned for sculpted lintels and King Itzamnaaj Bʼalam II (c. 200–900 CE)

Title: Uxmal
Definition: Puuc-region city noted for the Governor’s Palace and Circle of a Thousand Columns (c. 600–1000 CE)

Title: Chichén Itzá
Definition: Yucatán capital famous for the Temple of Kukulcán and mixed architectural styles (c. 600–1200 CE)

Title: Mayapan
Definition: postclassic Yucatán federation of Itza lineages (c. 1200–1440 CE)

Title: Moche
Definition: coastal Peruvian polity famed for its temples, painted ceramics, irrigation works, and warrior-priest elite (c. 100–800 CE)

Title: Tiwanaku
Definition: highland Bolivian centre governing the Lake Titicaca region, celebrated for its monumental platform mounds and raised-field agriculture (c. 300–1000 CE)

Title: Ebla
Definition: a powerful city-state in northwestern Syria with a palace bureaucracy, extensive trade networks, and its own cuneiform archive (c. 2500–2250 BCE).

Title: Mari
Definition: an Euphrates-river city-state famed for its royal palace archives, diplomatic correspondence, and centralized governance (c. 2900–1759 BCE).

Title: Teotihuacan
Definition: the dominant Mesoamerican city-state in the Valley of Mexico, noted for its pyramidal architecture and urban planning (c. 100–750 CE).

Title: Capua
Definition: an independent Italic city-state in Campania, prominent in Magna Graecia interactions and later allied with Rome (c. 9th–3rd centuries BCE).

Title: Cumae
Definition: a Greek colony and Italic city-state in Campania, noted for its Sibylline sanctuary and trade (c. 750–274 BCE).

Title: Praeneste
Definition: a Latin city-state in Latium, famed for the Sanctuary of Fortuna and its contests with Rome (c. 7th–1st centuries BCE).

Title: Saguntum
Definition: the Iberian city allied with Rome, whose siege precipitated the Second Punic War (c. 6th century BCE–219 BCE).

Title: Greek Polis
Definition: the characteristic city-state of ancient Greece.

Title: Athens
Definition: the polis renowned for democracy, philosophy, and maritime power during the Archaic and Classical periods (c. 800–322 BCE).

Title: Syracuse
Definition: Greek colony in Sicily under the Tyrants and later the Deinomenids, rival of Carthage (c. 734–212 BCE).

Title: Byzantion
Definition: the Megarian colony on the Bosporus, later Constantinople, a major Hellenic, Roman and Byzantine centre (c. 657 BCE–1453 CE).

Title: Massalia
Definition: the Phocaean colony on the southern Gaul coast, noted for trade and cultural exchange (c. 600 BCE–49 BCE).

Title: Cyrene
Definition: the Greek colony in Cyrenaica, a centre of Hellenistic philosophy and medicine (c. 631 BCE–96 BCE).

Title: Sparta
Definition: the militaristic polis in the Peloponnese, noted for its dual kingship and warrior society (c. 900–192 BCE).

Title: Corinth
Definition: major commercial and naval centre on the Isthmus, host of the Isthmian Games (c. 900–146 BCE).

Title: Thebes
Definition: leading city of Boeotia, defeated Sparta at Leuctra and briefly hegemonized Greece (c. 715–338 BCE).

Title: Argos
Definition: one of the oldest Peloponnesian states, noted for its rivalry with Sparta (c. 700–146 BCE).

Title: Miletus
Definition: Ionian polis famed for early Greek philosophy (Thales) and maritime trade (c. 1000–494 BCE).

Title: Ephesus
Definition: Ionian city renowned for the Temple of Artemis and as a major port (c. 1000 BCE–395 CE).

Title: Megara
Definition: strategic polis between Attica and the Peloponnese, founded the colony Byzantion (c. 750–146 BCE).

Title: Rhodes
Definition: Dorian island‐polis, famed for the Colossus and as a Hellenistic naval power (c. 408 BCE–42 CE).

Title: Kingdom Society
Definition: a Nation-State Society ruled by a monarch (hereditary or elective), whose authority is institutionalized through dynastic succession or regulated election among eligible royal lineages; social orders are organized around monarchical authority and court hierarchies.

Title: Early Dynastic Period of Egypt
Definition: the unified kingdom of Upper and Lower Egypt under its first pharaoh, Narmer, establishing centralized state institutions (c. 3100–2686 BCE).

Title: Vandal Kingdom
Definition: the North African state established by the Vandals, controlling Carthage and Mediterranean piracy (c. 435–534 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Kongo
Definition: a Central African Bantu monarchy on the Congo River, noted for early Christian conversion and provincial administration (c. 1390–1914 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Benin
Definition: a West African Edo monarchy in present-day Nigeria, renowned for brass casting and urban walls (c. 1180–1897 CE).

Title: Ashanti Empire
Definition: the Akan monarchy in present-day Ghana, famed for gold resources and centralized matrilineal governance (c. 1670–1902 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Dahomey
Definition: the Fon monarchy in present-day Benin, known for its army of female warriors and agropastoral economy (c. 1600–1904 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Ndongo
Definition: the Mbundu monarchy in present-day Angola, noted for its alliances and resistance to Portuguese expansion (c. 1556–1671 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Mutapa
Definition: the Shona monarchy on the Zimbabwe plateau, famed for gold trade and stone architecture (c. 1430–1760 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Buganda
Definition: the Bantu monarchy in present-day Uganda, noted for centralized kabaka rule and lake transport networks (c. 14th century–Present).

Title: Kingdom of Great Zimbabwe
Definition: the medieval Shona monarchy in southern Africa, noted for its monumental stone city (c. 11th–15th centuries CE).

Title: Oyo Empire
Definition: the Yoruba monarchy in present-day Nigeria, known for cavalry forces and tributary structure (c. 1300–1835 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Nepal
Definition: a Himalayan monarchy under the Shah dynasty, unifying small principalities (1768–2008 CE)

Title: Kingdom of the Lombards
Definition: the Germanic realm ruling much of Italy after the Gothic Wars, characterized by duchies and Arian Christianity (c. 568–774 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Afghanistan
Definition: a modern Afghan monarchy under the Barakzai dynasty (1926–1973 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Cambodia
Definition: the post-colonial Cambodian monarchy under Norodom Sihanouk (1953–1970 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Laos
Definition: the Lao constitutional monarchy under the Khun Lo lineage (1947–1975 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Montenegro
Definition: Balkan monarchy under the Petrović-Njegoš dynasty (1910–1918 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Albania
Definition: Zog I’s Albanian monarchy under the House of Zogu (1928–1939 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Egypt
Definition: the Hashemite-led Egyptian monarchy (1922–1953 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Iraq
Definition: the Hashemite monarchy in Mesopotamia (1921–1958 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Libya
Definition: the Senussi monarchy under Idris I (1951–1969 CE)

Title: Mutawakkilite Kingdom of Yemen
Definition: the Zaydi imamate-monarchy in North Yemen (1918–1970 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Tunisia
Definition: the Husainid monarchy under Muhammad VIII al-Amin (1956–1957 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Silla
Definition: the Korean kingdom that unified the peninsula, fostering Buddhist culture and centralized bureaucracy (c. 57 BCE–935 CE; unification 668 CE).

Title: Imperial State of Iran
Definition: the Pahlavi dynasty’s Persian monarchy (1925–1979 CE)

Title: Bagratid Kingdom of Armenia
Definition: the medieval Armenian monarchy under the Bagratuni (885–1045 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Georgia
Definition: the medieval and early modern Georgian monarchy (1008–1490 CE)

Title: Medieval Kingdom of Serbia
Definition: the Nemanjić dynasty’s Serbian monarchy (c. 1217–1346 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Makuria
Definition: the medieval Nubian Christian monarchy (c. 450–1500 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Alodia
Definition: the medieval Nubian monarchy in central Sudan (c. 6th–16th centuries CE)

Title: Kingdom of Jaffna
Definition: the Tamil monarchy in northern Sri Lanka (1215–1624 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Manipur
Definition: the Meitei monarchy in northeastern India (c. 1110–1891 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Kush
Definition: the ancient Kushite monarchy of Nubia (c. 1070 BCE–350 CE)

Title: Yamato State
Definition: the early Japanese state under the Yamato court, establishing imperial lineage and Shinto ritual authority (c. 250–710 CE).

Title: Second Kingdom of Burgundy
Definition: the West Frankish monarchy in southeastern Gaul (933–1378 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Urartu
Definition: the Iron Age monarchy in the Armenian highlands (c. 860 BCE–590 BCE)

Title: Kingdom of Cappadocia
Definition: the Hellenistic monarchy in central Anatolia (c. 320 BCE–17 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Bithynia
Definition: the Hellenistic monarchy in northwestern Anatolia (c. 297 BCE–74 BCE)

Title: Kingdom of Pontus
Definition: the Hellenistic monarchy in northern Anatolia (c. 281 BCE–62 BCE)

Title: Kingdom of Epirus
Definition: the Hellenistic monarchy in northwestern Greece (c. 330 BCE–167 BCE)

Title: Kingdom of Macedonia
Definition: the ancient Argead and Antigonid monarchy in northern Greece (c. 808 BCE–168 BCE)

Title: Odrysian Kingdom of Thrace
Definition: the ancient Thracian monarchy (c. 480 BCE–46 BCE)

Title: Kingdom of Saba
Definition: the ancient South Arabian monarchy in modern Yemen (c. 1000 BCE–275 CE)

Title: Kingdom of the Suebi
Definition: the Germanic monarchy in northwestern Iberia (409–585 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Nri
Definition: the Igbo monarchy in present-day Nigeria (c. 948 CE–1911 CE)

Title: Kassite Kingdom of Babylonia
Definition: the Babylonian dynasty under Kassite kings who preserved Mesopotamian culture under foreign rule (c. 1595–1155 BCE).

Title: Kingdom of Loango
Definition: the Bantu monarchy on the Atlantic coast of Central Africa (c. 15th–19th centuries CE)

Title: Kingdom of Matamba
Definition: the Ndongo–Matamba monarchy in central Angola (c. 1631 CE–1914 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Luba
Definition: the Luba monarchy in south-central Africa (c. 1585 CE–1889 CE)

Title: Bunyoro-Kitara Kingdom
Definition: the Bunyoro monarchy in present-day Uganda (c. 14th century CE–1894 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Rwanda
Definition: the Ruanda monarchy in the African Great Lakes (c. 11th century CE–1961 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Burundi
Definition: the Burundian monarchy in the African Great Lakes (c. 1680 CE–1966 CE)

Title: Kingdom of Tahiti
Definition: the Polynesian monarchy under the Pōmare dynasty (1788 CE–1880 CE)

Title: Sultanate of Malacca
Definition: the Malay Islamic monarchy on the Malay Peninsula (c. 1400 CE–1511 CE)

Title: Ayutthaya Kingdom
Definition: the Siamese kingdom centered at Ayutthaya, renowned for its maritime trade, multicultural court, and diplomatic networks across mainland Southeast Asia (1351–1767 CE).

Title: Thonburi Kingdom
Definition: the reunified Thai state under King Taksin, based at Thonburi, noted for restoring Siamese unity after Ayutthaya’s fall (1768–1782 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Mitanni
Definition: the Hurrian state in northern Mesopotamia and Syria, known for chariot warfare and diplomatic treaties with Egypt (c. 1500–1300 BCE).

Title: Rattanakosin Kingdom
Definition: the Chakri-dynasty Thai monarchy founded at Bangkok, commonly called the “Kingdom of Siam,” known for centralizing reforms and early modernisation (1782–1932; 1945–1949 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Lydia
Definition: the Anatolian kingdom credited with inventing coinage and ruled by Croesus at its height (c. 1200–546 BCE).

Title: Kingdom of Aksum
Definition: the northeastern African empire controlling the Red Sea trade routes, famous for its monumental stelae and coinage (c. 100–940 CE).

Title: Kingdom of England (Norman period)
Definition: a medieval European monarchy under William I and his successors, characterized by feudal consolidation and common law (1066–1154 CE).

Title: Kingdom of France (Capetian dynasty)
Definition: the West Frankish realm under the Capetians, noted for gradual centralization of royal authority (c. 987–1214 CE).

Title: Old Kingdom of Egypt
Definition: a unified Egyptian state under the Third to Sixth Dynasties, noted for its centralized bureaucracy and monumental pyramid construction (c. 2686–2181 BCE).

Title: Kingdom of Portugal
Definition: the Atlantic maritime kingdom in western Iberia that pioneered European overseas exploration (c. 1139–1910 CE).

Title: Crown of Castile
Definition: the medieval Iberian monarchy that expanded through the Reconquista and later united with Aragon (c. 1230–1479 CE).

Title: Crown of Aragon
Definition: the Mediterranean monarchy in northeastern Iberia that extended into Sicily and southern Italy (c. 1035–1479 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Scotland
Definition: the northern British kingdom noted for its distinct legal system and monarchy (c. 843–1603 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Poland
Definition: the Central European monarchy under the Piast and Jagiellon dynasties, pivotal in medieval European politics (c. 1025–1795 CE).

Title: Kingdom of France (Bourbon dynasty)
Definition: the Bourbon monarchy in western Europe, noted for its centralized absolutist government and cultural influence (c. 1589–1792 CE).

Title: Kingdom of England (Stuart and Hanoverian period)
Definition: the early Stuart and Hanoverian monarchy following the Union of the Crowns, establishing parliamentary traditions (c. 1603–1707 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Great Britain
Definition: the unified British monarchy after the 1707 Acts of Union, expanding maritime power and commercial empire (c. 1707–1800 CE).

Title: Kingdom of Sweden (House of Vasa and Age of Liberty)
Definition: a major Baltic power with centralized bureaucracy (c. 1523–1809 CE).

Title: Tribal Society
Definition: A society organized primarily around kinship ties, with social structure based on families, clans, or lineages, often with less centralized political authority than a state.

Title: Blackfoot

Definition: Plains buffalo hunters and gatherers (c. 1700–Present)

Title: Cheyenne
Definition: Primarily buffalo hunters of the Great Plains (c. 1700–Present)

Definition: Shared many cultural traits with Cheyenne, primarily buffalo hunters (c. 1700–Present)

Title: Shoshone
Definition: Hunter-gatherers primarily of the Great Basin and Plateau regions (c. 1500–Present)

Title: Inuit
Definition: Hunter-gatherers adapted to Arctic environments, primarily hunting marine mammals (c. 1200–Present)

Title: Horticultural
Definition: A tribal society that practices small-scale cultivation of plants, often using simple tools and shifting cultivation, typically more settled than hunter-gatherers.

Title: Hopi
Definition: Well-known for their traditional dryland farming of corn, beans, and squash (c. 1200–Present)

Title: Tupi
Definition: Historical indigenous groups of Brazil, many of whom practiced horticulture and lived in settled villages (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

Title: Mapuche
Definition: Indigenous people of south-central Chile and southwestern Argentina, known for traditional horticulture and other subsistence strategies (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

Title: Trobriand Islanders
Definition: Melanesian horticulturalists practicing yam cultivation and fishing (c. pre-Contact–Present)

Title: Ifugao

Title: Munduruku
Definition: Central Amazon horticulturalists known for riverine gardens (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

Title: Khasi
Definition: Northeastern Indian hill horticulturalists practicing terrace farming (c. pre-Colonial–Present)

Title: Hmong
Definition: Southeast Asian swidden horticulturalists (c. pre-Colonial–Present)

Title: Enga
Definition: Papua New Guinea highlands horticulturalists (c. pre-Contact–Present)

Title: Pueblo Tribal Societies

Title: Cherokee
Definition: Historically practiced settled agriculture, cultivating maize, beans, and squash (c. 1000–Present)

Title: Seminole
Definition: Practiced horticulture, cultivating corn, beans, and squash, alongside hunting and fishing (c. 1700–Present)

Title: Creek
Definition: Southeastern horticulturalists with complex town structures (c. 1700–Present)

Title: Choctaw
Definition: Southeastern horticulturalists, known for agriculture and mound-building (c. 1200–Present)

Title: Chickasaw

Title: Guarani

Title: Maasai

Title: Nenets

Title: Kyrgyz

Title: Sami

Title: Innovation Diffusion Process
